 1. BACKGROUND Introduction 1.1 The Government of China has requested Bank Group assistance in financing a water resources development project in catchment areas of the mid-Yangtze valley in the Provinces of Hubei and Hunan. Although the proposed project would include a broad range of water resource activities, the focus of the project would be on water resources for agriculture. The project would help improve large areas of irrigation and drainage in both provinces, develop new irrigated areas, construct a large concrete dam, and support key institutional development and reform in the water resource sector. It would also improve watershed protection through interventions in forestry, livestock and fodder improvement and provide supporting services for agriculture including improvements to fertilizer blending and soil testing capability. The provincial and local governments and the Ministry of Water Resources (MWR) prepared the project with assistance of missions from the Bank Group and the Food and Agriculture Organization/Cooperative Program in May and October 1993. Bank preappraisal and appraisal teams visited the proposed project areas in March/April and August/September 1994. A Population and Human Resources Development grant from the Government of Japan has helped support preparation of the project. The Agricultural Sector 1.2 Agriculture in China provides sustenance for 1.2 billion people and a livelihood for some 200 million farm families. Foodgrains occupy about 75 percent of the cultivated area, and intensive cultural practices in grain farming allow China to feed about 22 percent of the world's total population from 7 percent of the world's arable land. With growth in the economy, however, the urban/rural income gap is widening. Rural net income per capita in 1992 was Y 784, compared to a disposable after tax income of Y 1,826 for urban households. Increases in efficiency of production per unit area represent one means of narrowing this gap, while increasing the output of staple grains remains a priority of the Government of China. Since about half of China's cultivated agricultural land is irrigated, improvements to irrigation systems are an important means of increasing both reliability and productivity of agriculture and rural income. Further intensification will allow Chinese farmers to enjoy an increasing standard of living and to diversify production to meet the needs of an increasingly market oriented economy with more sophisticated food requirements. 1.3 Past progress in increasing grain production has been mixed, with significant increases after the introduction of rural reforms in 1978-84 followed by stagnating grain production in 1984-88. Production reached a new peak in 1990-92
 - 2 - following further investment in agriculture (principally in irrigation rehabilitation and expansion) and the introduction of reforms in grain procurement, prices, distribution and subsidies. Central planning of grain marketing has largely been eliminated, and wheat and com prices are approaching world levels as grain commodity exchanges develop in several centers, including Wuhan and Changsha. The value of grain production has declined from about one-half to one-third of the gross value of agricultural output as production of fruits, vegetables, and animal products has increased to meet changing consumer demand. Local governments have recognized these changes and now place a high priority on development of underutilized lands for the production of high value, nonstaple food and commercial crops. 1.4 Water resources development is critical to continued improvement in China's agricultural performance. The productivity of irrigated land averages about twice that of rainfed land, and is especially important for high-value crops like fruits and vegetables which need assured supplies of water. Irrigation currently accounts for about 70 percent of total grain output and about 80 percent of fruits and vegetables. In China, irrigation permits cropping intensities ranging from 120 percent in the northernmost areas of the country to 250 to 300 percent in the southern provinces, and yields under irrigation are among the highest in Asia. In some areas, flood control and drainage are also essential requirements for raising agricultural productivity. 1.5 The proposed project areas in Hubei and Hunan are well placed to benefit from policy reform and favorable attitudes toward investment by regional governments, if physical constraints to production can be overcome. Irrigated area productivity in these areas is limited by recurring drought in late summer, frequent flooding in some areas, relatively dry winters, and also by imbalanced fertilizer applications, particularly inadequate supplies of Oargely imported) potassium fertilizers. Irrigation rehabilitation and development, watershed protection, and improvements to fertilizer supply, however, can ease these constraints. The Water Resources Sector 1.6 Background. In aggregate terms, China has immense water resources, with total annual precipitation of some 6,200 billion m3 and total surface runoff of 2,700 billion m3. There are many rivers, streams and lakes, and more than 1,500 river basins that exceed 1,000 km2. The Yangtze River is the largest river in China and the third longest in the world; Dongting Lake, located in the project area, is the second largest lake in China. On a per capita basis, however, annual runoff averages about 2,300 m3, which is a quarter of the world average. Precipitation is variable and concentrated in the summer wet season, and many areas are subject to frequent droughts and floods. The geographical distribution of water resources is uneven. There are severe periodic water shortages particularly in the north and west of the country, and there is a growing macro water shortage in the Yellow River Basin, which is the primary source of water in the northern region. Available water resources are concentrated in the South where utilization is less than 20 percent of potential supply. Although the western areas are arid, population and demand there are also low.
 - 3 - 1.7 Since 1949, vast investments in water resource works and development have been undertaken. Irrigated area has expanded from about 20 million ha to nearly 50 million ha. Some 84,000 reservoirs for irnigation, flood control, power and water supply have been constructed with a combined gross storage capacity of 470 Bcm. Approximately 165,000 km of dikes, levees and coastal embankments have been constructed for flood protection and river control. There are now more than 5,500 irrigation systems having service areas exceeding 667 ha. Diesel or electric wells now total about 2.7 million. Total hydro generating capacity currently exceeds 40,000 MW. Water development and control projects have been implemented since ancient times throughout the country, and most rivers and streams are now used for irrigation, power generation, transport or urban water supply, some for all these purposes. 1.8 Flood Control. Many rivers are subject to seasonal flooding, and flood control works have been progressively constructed in threatened areas. These works include regulating reservoirs in the upper catchments, river dikes, flood retention basins, and flood protection embankments in the middle and lower reaches. Around 32 million ha of farmlands, as well as many urban areas, are now protected to some extent. However, only a few cities like Beijing, Harbin and Guangzhou are protected against 100-year floods, whereas in most other areas protection levels are against 40- to 50-year floods or less. Several major rivers, notably the lower Yellow and the middle Yangtze, are suspended up to 10 meters above the surrounding countryside, creating the potential for catastrophic floods over large areas. Some 450 million people live under risk of flooding in these basins. 1.9 Irrigation and Drainage. The gross irrigable area in the country is about 49 million ha of which, on average, 41.5 million ha are actually irrigated. The productivity of these lands is far higher than in rainfed areas. However, many irrigation systems were built to relatively low design standards due to lack of resources, and their technical performance is gradually degrading. Most irrigation schemes in China are "melons on a vine" systems. What distinguishes them from similar schemes in other countries is the extensive use of in-system storage. In addition to the headworks/reservoirs serving the systems, these systems have large numbers of small and medium reservoirs and ponds (the "melons"), which are the linked to the main canal system (the "vine"). The aggregate amount of such storage capacity for such systems is generally fairly large, and it enables relatively good overall agricultural performance despite inadequate maintenance. Drainage works are essential to allow cultivation in low lying areas subject to waterlogging and salinity. So far, drainage works have helped control waterlogging in 19 million ha and have reclaimed 4.8 million ha of saline lands. 1.10 Hydropower. Hydropower generating capacity totaled 37 GW and produced 125,000 GWh of power in 1991. Only about 9 percent of the estimated hydropower potential has been developed. However, most of the potential is located in the Southwest (70 percent), some 1,500 km away from the main demand centers. With power demand growing rapidly and estimated shortages of 20 percent in the late 1980s, the long gestation period for hydropower projects has also inhibited rapid development and utilization of hydroelectric resources. The largest source of electricity is thermal power
 - 4 - which is produced from coal mined in the north. Many of China's coal-fueled power stations are old and produce large amounts of pollutants, in contrast to hydropower which produces none. China's southeastern and eastern zones, which are the richest and fastest growing areas, are constrained in electricity supply. 1.11 Municipal and Industrial Water. Most of China's urban population of over 450 million have access to piped drinking water. Present water use for domestic purposes is relatively low, and in many cities water use is constrained by availability. In 1992, around 300 counties and 479 cities experienced water shortages. The situation needs urgent attention as urban water demand has been rising at over 10 percent annually, whereas supplies have been growing at 7 percent annually. China's industrial sector uses 26 billion m3 annually, which is high relative to output. Large amounts of polluting effluents are discharged by industry and there is little water recycling. 1.12 Transport. Many of the largest cities in China are located on rivers (Guangzhou, Chongqing, Nanjing, and Wuhan) or at the mouth of a river (Shanghai). River transport has been a major factor in the development of these cities and other areas adjacent to rivers. Even today, despite the development of road, rail and air links, water transport continues to play an important role. 1.13 Water Resource Institutions. Water resources, in the form of surface and ground water, are public property belonging to the State. Their utilization and exploitation are in principle controlled by various State Laws and Regulations, which are overseen by the Ministry of Water Resources (MWR) and administered by institutions at lower levels. Progressive decentralization and lack of resources, however, has weakened the ability of the center to control or influence development and management of water resources and to implement central water policies and statutes, and increasingly water resource decision- making is being transferred to the provincial level. A major problem facing water resource institutions at all levels is lack of revenue. To augment their income, many agencies engage in subsidiary activities, ranging from mechanical and electrical repairs to fish culture in reservoirs, to hotels and restaurants. 1.14 MWR, previously the Ministry of Water Resources and Electric Power, is the highest institution for management of water resources in China. Its duties include implementing the State Water Law (para. 1.18) and formulating regulations; long term planning of the country's water resources and its main rivers; water and soil conservation; organizing the construction of key national water resource projects; organizing flood prevention, control and response on major, multijurisdictional rivers; organization and leadership for dealing with droughts; promoting training; promoting rural water power; developing new technology; providing technical backup to other concerned agencies; and liaison with foreign agencies. MWR employs about 1.5 million workers nationwide, some 93 percent of whom work under provincial governments with the remainder directly under MWR. MWR also directly supervises the Water Resources and Hydroelectric Power Construction Corporation, administers seven regional river basin commissions and 13 institutions of higher education, and operates a number of research centers and specialized units such as the Remote Sensing Center, the Dam Safety Monitoring Center, and the
 National Headquarters for Flood Control and Drought Relief. A number of other institutions have links to MWR, including various universities, research centers and design institutes. 1.15 Under MWR are seven basin commissions responsible for major river basins including the Yangtze Basin and the Tai Lake Basin, each based in its respective basin. The duties of these commissions include monitoring and planning of water resource development, flood forecasting and warning, designing and executing large scale water resource and hydropower projects, guiding and coordinating work on soil and water conservation, and monitoring water quality and pollution in their respective basins. Except for project planning and approval, however, these commissions have inadequate authority over provincial jurisdictions to coordinate or control water resource development and management in their respective river basins, although they have greater powers during flood operations. 1.16 Most decisions concerning water development and allocations are made at the Provincial level, the main institution being the Provincial Water Resources Bureau (WRB). Provincial WRBs handle operation of flood protection works; design and implementation of projects; operation and maintenance (O&M) of large provincial irrigation and drainage infrastructure; and technical back up for lower level WRBs. In conjunction with MWR, the relevant River Basin Commission and other specialized agencies, Provincial WRBs are also responsible for planning of water resource development and soil conservation. Provincial WRBs have a number of affiliated institutions, such as the Provincial Hydraulic Design Institutes, Provincial Research Institutes, and general hydrology stations, and in many cases construction units which work on local and overseas contracts. 1.17 Prefecture and county WRBs deal with water resources at the local level. Their duties include construction and operation and maintenance (O&M) of local irrigation canals and systems within their jurisdiction; local level planning and development of water resources; implementation of various regulations and laws; monitoring of water quality and pollution levels; and flood control work. For larger projects or 'districts,' special Project Management Authorities are created to run key irrigation or drainage facilities such as large reservoirs or major conveyance systems. Prefecture and county WRB staff are responsible for O&M of medium irrigation and drainage facilities (e.g., submain canals, major branch canals, or large pumping stations), planning and distributing water, and levying water charges. Township level Water Management Stations (WMSs) are the lowest level government bodies involved in water management. They are mainly concerned with O&M of small irrigation, drainage and flood control works whose service areas are limited to the jurisdiction of a single township. At the village level, water users elect water management committees. These committees handle on-farm water management under the direction of higher level irrigation district staff; village unit size corresponds to about 400 to 500 farm families cultivating 200 to 250 ha, usually served by one or two lateral or sublateral canals.
 - 6 - 1.18 Legal Framework. The 'Water Law of the Peoples Republic of China" of 1988 (the Water Law) and the Water and Soil Conservation Law of 1989 are the basic laws controlling water resource management. FoUlowing the Water Law, a number of regulations have been promulgated covering, for example dam safety, land compensation and resettlement. The 'Environment Protection Law" is a general law covering among other things water pollution; the 'Water Pollution and Prevention Law" is a more specific law for controlling water pollution. The general provisions of the Water Law cover such aspects as comprehensive planning of water development, the ecology and planned alocation of water, and the State's rights to exercise unified administration of water resources with delegation of specific responsibilities. Water Resource Objectives and Plans 1.19 Overall Objectives and Strategy. The Govemment's primary objectives for the water resources sector are to encourage efficient water use and comprehensive water resource and river basin management; promote financial self-sufficiency and cost recovery; reduce water pollution; improve flood warning and protection; and undertake priority water development projects. The main steps to be taken for the achievement of these goals are policy and institutional reforms to improve water resource management; increased investment from domestic and foreign sources to improve key water resource infrastructure; and better regulation and monitoring of water pollution. 1.20 Improvement of Existing Irrigation Systems. Much of the existing water resource infrastructure was built to relatively low design and construction standards due to resource and materials limitations during the 1950s and 1960s. This impacts agriculture due to dams which are unsafe or cannot be operated at capacity, and irrigation systems which are inefficient and deteriorating rapidly and have excessive maintenance costs. In many cases, reservoirs and/or main canals have been constructed for irrigation, but the associated distribution systems were never completed. Completion, repair, rehabilitation and upgrading of existing facilities present a major opportunity for relatively high return, low cost investments, and have been a high priority of the Govemment and the Bank Group. 1.21 Planned Major Projects. There are two massive projects planned for the water resources sector which concern the Yangtze River Basin, although neither is related to the proposed project. The Three Gorges Project envisages the construction of a dam across the Yangtze River downstream of the "Three Gorges' near Yichang City in Hubei Province. The concrete gravity dam would have a height of 185 m, length of 2,500 to 2,800 m, flood control capacity of 22 billion m3, and installed electricity generating capacity of 18 GW. The primary purpose of the dam would be flood control, but in addition it would generate 84,000 GWh of power annually and improve navigation conditions along the middle and lower Yangtze River. The other major project is the South North Water Transfer (SNW`I) scheme, now in the planning stage. This would be a series of three large interbasin transfers from the water-surplus Yangtze River Basin to the water-short Yellow River Basin in the north. One SNWT route, the "Middle Route," would originate in northern Hubei from the Danjiangkou Reservoir, one of the largest in
 - 7 - China. Completion of stage II of Danjiangkou will increase total storage capacity from 10.2 to 19 Bcm, compared to mean annual inflow of about 39.8 Bcm from the Han River, and theoretically make some 15 Bcm available for transfer to the Yellow River Basin. It would also provide about 4 Bcm of regulated storage for hydropower and irrigation in Hubei. Current Lssues and Constraints in the Water Sector 1.22 Despite past achievements, China is facing problems and constraints in the water and irrigation sector. These problems are becoming increasingly severe as the population grows and the economy expands and becomes more market-driven. Two critical, macro water resource sector issues were noted above: (a) the growing large-scale water shortage in the North, particularly the Yellow River Basin (para. 1.6); and (b) weak river basin authorities without adequate statutory or regulatory basis for effective comprehensive river basin development and management (para. 1.15). The following key physical and institutional/financial constraints impact specifically on water resources for agriculture. 1.23 Physically: (a) many large irrigation schemes constructed in the 1950s and 1960s were hastily designed and built with low quality materials and equipment. Now, most require major rehabilitation and upgrading; (b) many such schemes still lack irrigation distribution and drainage networks at the tertiary and farm level. Such networks were to have been constructed by local governments, which lacked the incentive to do so due to historical deficiencies in grain pricing; (c) large tracts of cultivated land have been affected by waterlogging and secondary soil salinization. This is largely due to excessive irrigation without effective drainage to control the water table rise; (d) uncontrolled construction of tubewells, prompted by government subsidies, has led to overexploitation of groundwater, falling water tables, and land subsidence, especially in the North China Plain; (e) investment and maintenance for on-farm facilities, formerly a communal responsibility during the slack winter season, has been disrupted by the household responsibility system, under which households tend to look after their own contracted interests; and (f) operation and maintenance (O&W has often been inadequate. Maintenance resources allocated by the central and provincial governments have frequently not been matched adequately by funding from counties and townships. 1.24 Institutionally: (a) management of most medium and large irrigation schemes is fragmented, which makes efficient overall system operation difficult. Low level WRBs are responsible for O&M of canals only within their administrative jurisdiction, and the Project Management Authority at the system level has only limited authority over operation, performance and standards of lower level WRBs, which are controlled by the local government administration; (b) direct participation by the farmers in system operation and decision making, except at the lowest levels, is very limited. This reduces their sense of ownership and responsibility, and consequently their willingness to pay water charge rates sufficient for long-run sustainability; (c) water charges are frequently too low to cover full costs. In effect, they often become a ceiling, holding down water revenues needed to improve maintenance even where farmers are willing to
 - 8 - pay higher water charges for better service; (d) water demand for municipalities and industry is growing rapidly and in some areas, notably the lower Yellow River basin, reallocation of water is already reducing irrigated area. No systematic institutional or legal framework is in place to handle these competing water demands and reallocation requirements; (e) flood control and warning is increasingly important to promote and protect rapid economic growth, especially in the major river basins like the Yangtze and Yellow. But there is no established method of collecting fees for such services to make them self-sustaining; (f) water pollution from urban areas and dispersed rural industries is growing rapidly and has proven difficult to control despite strong environmental legislation; (g) cuts in central Government budgets for water resource development beginning in 1980 have curtailed measures to alleviate some of these constraints, and development of new water resources has not kept pace with demand from agriculture, industry and urban centers. Although state capital investment has rebounded somewhat since 1985, it still falls short of pre-1980 levels in real terms; and (h) decentralization and reduced central investment resources have diminished the ability of MWR to guide and influence comprehensive water resource development and policy systematically. Past Bank Support and Key Lessons Learned 1.25 Past Bank Support for Water Resources in Agriculture. Starting with the North China Plain Agricultural Project (Cr. 1261-CHA) in 1982, the Bank has so far financed 15 agricultural projects in China having major water resources components with associated lending of some $3.9 billion and covering a total irrigated area of about 3.8 million ha. Although some of these projects included construction of new irrigation, in most cases they aimed at improving existing irrigation and drainage systems. All projects have financed physical works as well as a wide range of supporting rural infrastructure and services. These projects were mostly implemented by WRBs at provincial, county and township levels, and implementation performance of these local level institutions has generally been positive. Three projects with major water resource components have closed-the North China Plain, Heilongjiang Land Reclamation Project (Ln. 2261-CHA/ Cr. 1347-CHA), and Pishihang-Chaohu Area Development Project (Ln. 2579-CHA/Cr. 1606-CHA); all were reported to be highly successful. 1.26 Lessons Learned. Key lessons from previous water resource projects are that: (a) detailed organizational and staffing arrangements should be formulated and agreed before implementation; (b) countexpart funding should be agreed before implementation; (c) project design should support the 'user pays' principle, and user (farmer) participation should be explicitly built into project planning, implementation and operation; (d) flood protection investments should include cost recovery from beneficiaries; (e) irrigation and water conservancy projects should include provisions for unified irrigation system management based on hydraulic units; and (f) projects should include institutional development support for strengthening of provincial and local WRBs. These lessons have been incorporated into the proposed project.
 -9 Rationale for Bank Involvement 1.27 The proposed project is consistent with the Bank Group's Country Assistance Strategy for China distributed to the Board in August 1993. That strategy emphasized income enhancement and poverty alleviation as the highest priorities in the agriculture sector. It also highlighted the need to improve water resource planning, especially in flood prone areas, and coordination between provinces in water resource development. Although not designed specifically for poverty alleviation, the proposed project would benefit mainly rural dwellers many of whom have poverty-level incomes, and one of the major subprojects is located in a remote region which is classified as a poverty area. The project would also provide substantial direct environmental benefits through flood control by the Jiangya Dam commanding the Lishui Basin in Hunan, and from soil conservation under the forestry and grassland components. Bank involvement will also help to promote better policy and institutional development and change in the water resources sector. The project would support establishment of self-financing irrigation districts based on farmer participation and of comprehensive river basin management for the Lishui River Basin in Hunan, both of which are primary elements of Bank and Chinese water resources policy. The project would also further technological innovation in water resources: Jiangya Dam would employ a relatively new, more cost- effective construction technique and would be the one of the highest dams of its type in the world when completed, and several of the irrigation subprojects would incorporate canal automation on a pilot basis for improved operational efficiency.
 - 10 - 2. THE PROJECT AREA 2.1 The project area would be the mid-Yangtze River Basin in the provinces of Hubei and Hunan. In Hubei, five water resource subprojects-Dongfeng, Zhenghe, Yindan, Wenxia and Sihu-and four nonwater resource subprojects would be located in 24 counties/municipalities which cover about 2.0 million ha of cultivated land. In Hunan, three water resource subprojects-Jiangya Dam, Tieshan and Liuduzhai-would be located in nine counties and one municipality covering some 0.8 million ha of cultivated land. Yangtze River Basin 2.2 Background. The Yangtze River is the largest river in China, and one of the largest and the third longest in the world. The Yangtze Basin population exceeds 350 million, of whom 86 percent are rural, and the Yangtze Basin region accounts for about 40 percent of the country's total agricultural and industrial output. The total navigable length of the river system including tributaries exceeds 70,000 kin, about 60 percent of the country's total. Annual average precipitation is 1,100 mm, concentrated almost entirely between April and October, with the heaviest rainfall during June, July and August. Mos. areas of the basin are affected by subtropical monsoons which come from both the southeast and the southwest. Snowmelt runoff comprises less than 10 percent of the annual stream flow. 2.3 The Yangtze River has been divided into three reaches: the upper reach from the headwaters rising in the high mountains of Qinghai Province and passing through Tibet, Yunnan and Sichuan down to Yichang City in Hubei, the site of an existing major low-head power dam-Gezhouba-and shiplock, at the end of the famous Three Gorges; the middle reach from Yichang descending some 1,000 km through large, low-lying alluvial plains with many lakes to Poyang Lake; and the lower reach from Poyang Lake to the sea north of Shanghai. The basin encompasses about 1.8 million kim2, almost 20 percent of the country. About 90 percent of flood volumes at Yichang are generated in the upper Yangtze basin above Cuntan, and flood waters generated in the Three Gorges area between Cuntan and Yichang are the main source of flash floods in the middle reach where the project areas are located. 2.4 In the middle reach, the combination of hydrology and topography makes the region prone to frequent severe and widespread flooding. As a result, it was sparsely populated until the seventh century when migrants from the north began construction of dikes, embankmnents and flood diversion works. Major floods in this century occurred in 1931, 1935 and 1954, and during 1954, 8 million ha were affected and 320,000 people died. Dongting Lake is connected directly to the Yangtze River and plays an important role as a diversion area for regulating Yangtze River floods in the region. Although this
 - 11 - can lead to considerable flood losses in the Dongting area, it averts more widespread serious flooding and possible dike failure in other areas. However, the size of Dongting has been continuously shrinking (from 4350 km2 in 1949 to 2,691 km2 in 1983) due to polderization and sedimentation from Yangtze flood waters diverted into the lake, and this has progressively increased flooding in the region. 2.5 With rapid economic development, rising incomes, growing population, and increasing land pressure in the basin, the need to provide better flood protection and prevention measures is becoming increasingly urgent. Timely and accurate flood forecasting is essential to ensure correct operating decisions for diversion areas and for major flood control reservoirs. An effective flood warning system is needed to warn the population with as much lead time as possible. Mistakes and delays based on faulty data and poor communications can cost billions of Yuan and many tens of thousands of lives. The Yangtze Basin Comprehensive Development Plan gives top priority to improved flood control in the middle and lower reaches, including nonstructural measures such as improving meteorological and hydrological monitoring networks, flood forecasting, and communications and warning for flood control. 2.6 Flood Control Infrastructure. Although dikes and embankments had been constructed for centuries, flood protection along the Yangtze was given more impetus in the 1950s, and in 1952 a flood protection program was launched for the Jingjiang Plain, which is the rich and highly fertile area lying north of the Yangtze between Yichang and Wuhan in Hubei. The Jingjiang Levee was constructed along 180 km of the left bank of the Yangtze River in Hubei, and raised in some places to 16 m above normal river flows; the Shashi flood retention basin in Hubei was completed; flood intake sluices, regulating dams and retention basins were built on the right bank in the Dongting Lake region of Hunan province; the multipurpose Danjiangkou Reservoir was built on the upper Han; and other works were carried out to reinforce dikes on tributaries like the Han. On the northern side, these works provide protection from floods with a return period of about 1 in 20 years to large cities and industries, and to about 2.0 million ha of irrigated land and a population of about 25 million in the Jingjiang Plain between the Yangtze and Han Rivers. However, the level of protection on the south side is generally less in order to reduce flood levels at Wuhan, protecting only from four to seven year return interval floods in the 400,000 ha of land reclaimed around Dongting Lake. The Lishui River is also a primary contributor to Dongting Lake flooding and among all medium-size rivers in China has had the most serious floods of this century. In the Lishui floods of 1935, some 40,000 lives were lost; protection levels are still low, and the same flood today would cause 150,000 deaths. The Lishui River and Dongting Lake area have had serious floods in 33 out of the 44 years since 1949, which is a serious detriment to economic growth in northern Hunan. Improved flood control in the Lishui Basin with the proposed Jiangya Dam would contribute to Yangtze River flood protection and reduce flood levels in Dongting Lake, and Jiangya is considered a national priority. 2.7 Yangtze (Chang Jiang) Water Resources Commission. The Yangtze Water Resources Commission (YWRC) was established and headquartered in Wuhan in 1950 and is responsible for: collection and analysis of hydrological, geological and
 - 12 - socioeconomic data; comprehensive water resource planning; design and construction of medium and large water and hydropower projects; advising on river regulation; flood control planning and operation in the middle and lower Yangtze; research and monitoring of water resources, including environmental aspects; and implementation of water and soil conservation works. It plays a key role in planning and design of large projects in the Yangtze Basin, and a recent major activity has been investigation and design of the proposed Three Gorges Dam. Climate, Topography, and Soils 2.8 Climate. The project area has a continental monsoon, subtropical climate with hot, humid summers and cool dry winters. Late summer drought is common to all project areas with a frequency as high as one in two years, while flooding can be expected in one of every four to five years. Average monthly temperature varies from 3C in January to 28C in July, but temperatures commonly fall below freezing in the winter and rise above 38C in the summer. The average frost-free period is 230 to 270 days. Annual average rainfall varies from about 840 mm to 1,300 mm, with most rain faling between April and October. Selected climatological data are given in Annex 1, Table 1. 2.9 Topography and Soils. Topography varies considerably between project areas, from dissected hills in the Liuduzhai and Tieshan areas in Hunan and parts of the Dongfeng and Wenxia areas of Hubei to generaUy open sloping plains on the areas adjacent to the Yangtze and Han Rivers in the other project areas. Soils vary from various subgroups of weathered oxisols and ultisols, acid in reaction, in upland areas of Hubei and Hunan to a range of paddy soils, broadly classified as anthropic hydruists which are neutral to alkaline, in the established irrigation areas on the plains adjacent to major rivers. The areas have been extensively mapped in terms of physical and chemical characteristics. A repeated pattern of low nitrogen and phosphorus status is seen in all soils, while potassium deficiency occurs naturaUy in upland red (oxisol, ultisol) soils and in the alluvial irrigated soils after some years of intensive cropping. Micronutrient deficiencies (Zinc, Boron and Molybdenum) also occur in all areas. Socioeconomic Conditions 2.10 Population totals 54.5 milion in Hubei and 60.7 million in Hunan, of which nearly 80 percent are rural. Per capita rural income in 1991 was Y 627 and Y 689, respectively, compared to the national average of about Y 784. Average rural household size is 4 to 5 people. Farm sizes are small, with only about 0.08 ha per capita in Hubei and 0.07 ha per capita in Hunan. Hubei has 15 prefectures and 70 counties/municipalities, of which 24 counties/municipalities are in the project area; Hunan has 14 prefectures/ municipalities and 107 counties, of which 9 (excluding the benefiting areas of Jiangya Dam) are in the project area. In the project area counties and municipalities, population totals about 9.2 million. Project areas in Hubei are already heavily irrigated and have an average per capita income of Y 785. In Hunan, however, project areas at present have little or no irrigation and average per capita income is only Y 377, with 17 percent of households below the absolute poverty line (currently about Y 320 per capita).
 - 13 - Agriculture and Water Resources 2.11 Agriculture. Existing agricultural development is concentrated in valley floors, although hill areas are used for irrigation in the Liuduzhai subproject area in Hunan. Average cropping intensity exceeds 200 percent in both Hubei and Hunan, and is determined by the reliability of irrigation water supply, length of growing season (mainly determined by elevation) and adequacy of drainage. Below about 400 m elevation, warmer temperatures allow triple cropping of early and late rice followed by rapeseed, wheat or green manure. At higher elevations and with less reliable irrigation, rice is double cropped with rapeseed or wheat. Smaller areas of spring maize, peanut and sesame are grown in Hunan, while tubers and cotton are found in Hubei. Average yields of main crops are relatively high-5.5 t/ha for paddy, 2.3 t/ha for wheat, and 1.1 t/ha for rapeseed in Hubei; and 5.8 t/ha for paddy, 1.6 t/ha for wheat and 1.0 t/ha for rapeseed in Hunan. Hunan is the largest provincial producer of rice in China, and Hubei is the fifth largest. 2.12 Rainfed cropping of mid-slope areas comprises annual spring and winter sown species such as peanut, maize, brassicas and sweet potato with hand-watered vegetables in household plots. Tea is cultivated in both Hunan and Hubei, and Hunan is the second largest provincial producer of tea. Yields of tea are restricted by cultivation at relatively low altitudes of around 400 m (in Hubei), poor management, and low fertilizer use in both Provinces. 2.13 Livestock plays an important part in the farming system, providing meat, eggs, milk and draft power, and also an important source of additional income. The main livestock is pigs. Backyard pig and poultry production based on feeding of household residues is common in the project areas, with a typical household fattening two or three pigs per year and keeping about 12 chickens for home consumption. Higher mountain areas in the north and west of Hubei are used for cattle breeding and act as a source of yearling animals for fattening in the lowlands where sufficient high quality feed is available. 2.14 Water Resources. Hubei and Hunan have large surface and groundwater resources with thousands of rivers and streams. In Hubei, the largest water resources are the Yangtze and Han Rivers, and the Sihu (four lakes) interlinked lake system in the southwest. Hunan has four major rivers, the Xiangjiang, Zijiang, Yuanjiang, and Lishui; most of the river flow in Hunan goes to Dongting Lake and thence into the Yangtze River. Hubei and Hunan have about 2.6 million ha and 2.5 million ha of irrigation, most of which is supplied from reservoirs; Hunan for example has over 13,000 small, medium and large size reservoirs with total storage of 29 Bcm.

C. HuNAN COMPONENT Jiangya Multipurpose Dam 3.15 Jiangya Multipurpose Dam ($290.2 million) would be located near Jiangya Town in Cili County, on the Loushui River in the Lishui River Basin. One of the four largest rivers in Hunan, the Lishui River has had the worst floods of this century among medium size rivers in China, and it is a primary source of widespread flooding in the low-lying area west of Dongting Lake. This area has a high concentration of population and is an important center for agricultural and industrial production, and frequent flooding there affects both large numbers of people and economic growth and development in Hunan. To reduce flooding risks, the Hunan Government has decided to construct several dams in the Lishui Basin: first Jiangya Dam, to be followed by the Zaoshi and Yichongqiao Dams in the future. Studies indicate that Jiangya will give the largest and most immediate reduction in flooding damage. Its completion for flood protection by 1997 has been promised by national leaders after recent large flood losses; this is one reason for use of roller compacted concrete (RCC) technology, which is the most rapid construction method for large concrete dams now known. China is a leader in RCC dam construction. 3.16 The main purpose of Jiangya is flood control. It would also include 300 MW of hydropower capacity and a boatlift located on the left bank which would accommodate boats of 20 tons and an estimated annual volume of 40,000 tons. The dam would be a RCC gravity type with maximum dam height of 128 m, crest length of 336 m, and total concrete volume of 1.4 Mcm. At completion, it would be one of the world's highest and largest RCC dams. The overall storage capacity would be 1.7 Bcm, of which 740 Mcm would be reserved for flood control. Some 950 ha of farm land would be inundated and about 12,587 people would be relocated. The silt load of the river is low, and the reservoir life should exceed 200 years.

SELF-nFNANCING IRRIGAnON AND DRAINAGE DISTRcrS 3.23 As the Chinese economy becomes more market-oriented, the long-run sustainability of irrigation and drainage will depend increasingly on self-financing of irrigation facilities and operations. The proposed project would promote development of a new concept of self-financing irrigation and drainage districts (SIDDs), through which existing irrigation districts would be converted into legal, self-financing entities (Annex 6). Key ingredients in achieving the latter are to provide unified management which is based on hydraulic (not administrative) boundaries for efficiency, and is responsive to the users and demand; and to give more management responsibility and control to the farmers/users who have the greatest interest in the success of water resource facilities under the project. 3.24 Support under the project for SIDD establishment is built into each subproject, and would start initially in Zhanghe subproject in Hubei and Tieshan subproject in Hunan (paras. 4.10-4.12, para. 5.19 and Annex 6). Based on experience with these pilot subprojects, SIDD concepts and procedures would be refined and applied to other water resource subprojects gradually. SIDD establishment would involve institutional development at two levels: (a) the overall subproject or system level, where a Water Supply Corporation (WSC) would be established with unified responsibility for the irrigation system and its O&M, similar to TRWSC already established at Tieshan; and (b) the hydraulic unit level within the system, where Water User Associations (WUAs) would be established and managed by farmers. WSCs and WUAs would be organized as hydraulic units (e.g., by canal or lateral), not according to administrative (e.g., county) boundaries. For irrigation subprojects, project financing would include construction of management buildings, equipment, computers, vehicles, training, study tours, and consultancy services to support development of WSCs and WUAs, and installation of water measuring devices for canals, offtakes and reservoirs. WSCs would gradually take over the responsibilities of the present Management Authorities and the local WRBs for construction of project works and O&M of the subprojects, and they would be responsible for establishment, monitoring and support of WUAs. Before construction, farmer groups
 - 23 - would have to agree voluntarily to form legal WUAs, contribute to construction of the system, and assume responsibility for O&M including full responsibility for their local system and payment of specified water fees to the WSC. The provincial WRB would assist through training, technical assistance, development, and monitoring of procedures and processes for WSC and WUA establishment and operation, and preparation of model Articles of Association for the WSCs and model By-Laws for the WUAs, which would include representation of women. Agreement was reached at negotiations that Hubei and Hunan would prepare and adopt time-bound implementation plans by December 31, 1995 satisfactory to the Bank/lIDA for establishment and operation of WSCs and WUAs, and thereafter carry out the implementation plans in a manner satisfactory to the Bank/IDA. I. ENVIRONmENT AND RESETrLEmENT 3.32 Environment. The project as a whole is classed as a Category A development for the Bank Group's Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) purposes, mainly due to the Jiangya Dam and reservoir component. The EIA was prepared by the Research Institute for Water Resources Protection of the Yangtze under YWRC (Annex 7). The final EIA report, incorporating Bank Group comments, was received by the Bank Group in April 1994, and the Summary EIA has been submitted to the Bank Group's Public Information Center. For Jiangya, potential adverse impacts are limited by the remote location, degraded catchment conditions due to a long history of occupation and exploitation and lack of significant urban or industrial development in the catchment. The five rare and endangered flora species that will be affected are well represented outside the area. For irrigation subprojects, potential adverse impacts are very limited because the investments are mainly for rehabilitation. However, there are several environmental issues
 - 26 - at Sihu, for which the project is not responsible but which it would assist; in particular, low-lying areas would be filled with dredge spoil from the project to reduce snail and mosquito breeding areas for schistosomiasis and malaria control. In addition, Sihu faces many development pressures unrelated to the project which may threaten local water quality, and a specialized environmental study would be financed under the project. A comprehensive Environmental Management and Monitoring Plan (EMMP) has been prepared covering both Jiangya and Sihu (Annex 7). LHPC has established an Environment and Resettlement Panel (ERP) for Jiangya Dam, and would implement the EMMP for Jiangya and monitor environmental conditions in the Lishui Basin. 3.33 Resettlement ($38.3 million). Jiangya Dam will require resettlement of 12,587 people in two counties in Hunan and one in Hubei. An additional 3,196 people, who will lose their land but not their housing, will also receive economic rehabilitation. The Resettlement Action Plan (RAP) for Jiangya was prepared by Wuhan University of Hydraulic and Electrical Engineering, the Hunan Hydro and Power Design Institute, and YWRC, and Benchmark Targets for resettlement progress have been agreed and are being monitored (Annex 7). Already, 567 people have been resettled from the dam site. The remaining resettlement would be done in five stages: to elevation 138 m (421 people) by April 1995; 138-160 m (3,574 people) by September 1995; 160-200 m first group (2,050 people) by December 1995 and second group (3,363 people) by December 1996; and 200-236 m (3,179 people) by December 1997. Some 29 village sites and six market towns would be developed. About 75 percent of the people would be given farmland at higher elevations to grow fruits, tea and Chinese medicinal herbs; 19 percent would get jobs in township and village enterprises, and 6 percent would be employed in aquaculture and grain farming. LHPC would be responsible for the overall implementation of Jiangya Dam resettlement, and would make agreements with Resettlement Bureaus in the affected counties to carry out their respective resettlement plans. LHPC has contracted with Wuhan University for supervision and monitoring of the RAP and has established an Environment and Resettlement Panel (ERP). Agreements were reached at negotiations that: (a) the Borrower would take all steps necessary to ensure that Hubei, Hunan and LHPC carry out their respective parts of the EMMP and RAP; (b) Hubei and Hunan would cause the affected counties to enter into appropriate agreements with LHPC satisfactory to the Bank/IDA by September 30, 1995, to carry out the RAP and to maintain their resettlement offices with adequate and competent staff acceptable to the Bank/IDA to implement the RAP; (c) Hubei would carry out its responsibilities under the EMMP with respect to the Sihu subproject; (d) Hunan would take all steps necessary to ensure that LHPC carries out its responsibilities under the EMMP and RAP; and (e) LHPC would (i) operate and maintain the ERP with respect to the EMMP and RAP andfor Jiangya Dam; (ii) maintain its ERD with competent staff in adequate numbers and functions acceptable to the Bank/IDA, to manage, coordinate and monitor the implementation of the EMMP and the RAP; (iii) ensure that all actvities for its parts of the project comply with environrmental guidelines satisfactory to the Bank/IDA; (iv) take all necessary measures to mitigate adverse environmental impacts caused by the dam construction; and (v) implement the EMMP and RAP in a timely manner. AGRICULTURAL BENEFrrs Water Resource Subprojects 5.1 The proposed irrigation sub-projects would increase agricultural output and incomes from about 321,500 ha at relatively low cost, on average about $170/ha for rehabilitation covering 271,300 ha in Hubei and about $1,600 for 50,200 ha of new irrigation in Hunan (Annex 10). Benefits would mostly result from carrying out essential works which have hitherto been deferred due to lack of funds, and from investments in improved operations with more user participation to meet the needs of high input/output farming systems. It is expected that creation of SIDDs and WUAs under the project would lead the way to more general reform of irrigation and drainage system management in the two provinces, which have a total of 5.1 million ha of irrigated lands, and provide lessons for other provinces. In Sihu, the project would improve flood control conditions for about 336,500 ha of cultivated lands and improve the productivity of 28,000 ha, and for Sihu and Dongting Lake areas would help improve future infrastructure investment and operation through development of hydraulic models for design, investment and real time operating systems. Tieshan subproject would also supply municipal water to Yueyang City. 5.2 Incremental agricultural production from irrigation and drainage subprojects would come from the intensification of irrigation on existing areas achieved through improvement of drainage and irrigation reliability particularly for rice, wheat, rapeseed, and cotton production, expansion of irrigated area by reclamation of poorly drained lowland in Hubei, and reclamation of upland wastelands in Hunan. There would be no change or only minor changes in the crop mix for Zhanghe, Dongfeng, Yindan, and Wenxia subprojects, but in Sihu more substantial changes in crop areas (including expansion of winter cropping) are expected within the same mix of crops due to better drainage. Changes in Hunan generally involve introduction of irrigated cropping systems into rainfed and wasteland areas, rather than changes in existing cropping patterns in already irrigated areas. 5.3 The project would result in increased production of a number of irrigated crops, of which the most important are rice, wheat, cotton and rapeseed. The bulk of incremental output would come from increased yields and to a lesser extent from increases in cropping intensities. In Hubei, crop yields would on average increase by about 10-15 percent through a combination of drainage and water supply improvement and balanced fertilizer use; e.g., rice (paddy) yields would rise from about 6.3 t/ha without the project to 7.1 t/ha. In Hunan, yields are currently more restricted by poor water availability than
 - 44 - in Hubei and would increase from a lower base yield. Unirrigated or partly irrigated land would be brought under full irrigation, and larger yield increases of about 25 percent-40 percent are expected; rice yields would rise from about 4.9 t/ha to 6.2 t/ha. In both provinces in most areas, full development yields would be obtained in two years after completion of improvements, and full area benefits would be attained over four or five years, so that full development benefits would accrue at the end of year six or seven, with relatively little change in output during initial years. At full development, the output of paddy rice would rise about 26 percent above present levels from 1.4 million tons to 1.8 million tons, wheat by 21 percent from 0.4 million tons to 0.5 million tons, cotton by 236 percent from 22,000 tons to 74,000 tons, and rapeseed by 39 percent from 62,000 tons to 86,000 tons. The anticipated increase in production reflects a combination of greater water availability and better water control in average years, and an increased ability of the system to meet shortfalls in drought years. In Sihu, increases in cropping intensity would play a major role as 28,000 ha which are presently single cropped would be double cropped after improved drainage is provided. Nonwater Resource Subprojects in Hubei 5.4 Aquaculture. Improvement of 17 lakes (12,593 ha) would increase annual fish, turtle, and crab production by about 100 percent from about 6,400 t to 12,800 t. For fish production ponds (581 ha), the fish production target would be 7.5 t/ha/yr for both new and improved ponds, compared to the average current production of about 4.5 t/halyr from existing, unimproved ponds. Carp production from the new production ponds would be about 1,600 t/yr from 216 ha; and the incremental production from improved productions ponds would be about 1,100 t/yr, rising from 1,640 t/yr to 2,740 t/yr for 365 ha. The yield from nursery ponds would be about 6 t/ha/yr, representing an average incremental increase of about 2.4 t/halyr for improved nursery ponds; fingerlings would be used to stock the small lakes, reservoirs and production ponds under the project. Production of fish fingerlings would thus increase by about 1,200 t/yr, with about 700 t/yr from new nursery ponds (117 ha) and about 500 t/yr from improved nursery ponds (205 ha). Five new fish hatcheries would produce a total of about 550 million fry (3 cm) each year. A pilot 1-ha turtle farm would produce about 9 t/yr of market-sized turtles, and a new 4.2-ha turtle hatchery would produce about 11 t/yr of seed turtles (100 g each). At full development, total incremental fish production from the project lakes, reservoirs, and ponds would be about 9,100 t/yr with an estimated gross incremental revenue of about Y 40 million annually. 5.5 Forestry and Grasslands/Livestock. The project would support more intensive use of 36,400 ha of poor and marginal land in Hubei for forestry and grassland/livestock development. Some of this land, which belongs to the counties, is not used while the rest is used by poor farmers with little regard to conservation and the long term capacity of the land. As a result, returns are low and likely to fall in the long term. By introducing better, more sustainable utilization of these lands, the project would increase incomes, particularly of the rural poor, and improve soil and water conservation. Better quality seedlings, balanced fertilizer application, reduced planting densities appropriate to the soils involved and improved crop management are expected to lift yields
 - 45 - above current yields in Hubei for the economic forest crops proposed. Economic forest plantings would commence bearing in years 6 and 7 and ultimately reach yields of 13,000 kg/ha for peaches/plums/pears, 12,500 kg/ha for citrus, 5,000 kg/ha for chestnut, 750 kg/ha for tea, 150 kg/ha for eucommia (medicinal plant), and 4,000 kg/ha for lycium (Chinese wolfberry); these yield projections are modest compared to the experience of adjoining provinces. Timber and protection forest would benefit from wider use of better quality seedlings and fertilizer. Timber forestry would produce a total yield of firewood, poles and pulp timber of 182 m3/ha after 11 years for poplar and 139 m3/ha after 15 years for slash pine. Protection forestry would be limited to a 70 percent extraction and would yield 74 m3/ha and 176 m3/ha of pulp and firewood timber after 20 years. Average annual wood production would rise by about 269,000 m3 of which 60-70 percent would be fuelwood and the rest timber. Fruit output, at full development, would rise by 64,000 tons. For the subproject counties these represent increases of about 75 percent and 150 percent, respectively, over present output levels. 5.6 Grasslands for livestock fattening would be adequately fertilized and drained or irrigated as required in the lowlands. Lowland farms would plant 1 ha of pasture to produce three fattened steers from 12,000 kg/ha dry matter, while upland farms would plant 2 ha to achieve the same result. In the case of livestock, the project would result in an annual incremental production of 49,000 cattle at full development. In comparison, the present cattle population in the subproject counties is around one million. 5.7 Soil Improvement. The six fertilizer blending factories under the project would produce, at full development, 180,000 tons annually of compound ferdlizer. This would be sufficient for about 6 percent of the total area planted to rice and wheat in the subproject counties. The use of better balanced fertilizer would help overcome specific nutrient deficits thereby increasing crop yields, increase returns to fertilizer input, and also reduce the use of chemical ferdlizer (mostly nitrogenous fertilizer) by 67,000 tons. Project funded factories would also encourage private sector development of blending units. JLUNGYA DAM BENEFms 5.11 The main benefits of the Jiangya subproject come from the control of floods, and supply of power and energy to the Hunan power grid (Annex 10). Other benefits will also result from improved water supply for irrigation and domestic uses, improved river transportation and tourism. Although these latter benefits are important, they are small compared to the flood control and power benefits and have been omitted from the analysis. Flood Control 5.12 The Li River (Lishui) originates in mountainous country and is joined by two main tributaries, the Lou River on which Jiangya would be located and the Xie River,
 - 47 - before flowing into a low lying lake and plains area called Songli District which is west Dongting Lake. The river morphology in the lake area is extremely complicated. The Li flows into west Dongting Lake which is connected to the Yangtze River. In the lake area, agricultural and populated areas are located in "polder" areas protected by 531 km of dikes. Flooding in Songli District is frequent and severe. Even after massive work in raising and strengthening dikes, the current flood protection standard is estimated at only one in four to seven years, and protection is deteriorating because of sedimentation in the Dongting Lake area, which is primarily due to diversion of flood flows from the Yangtze. 5.13 Protection against floods with 30-year return period can be provided in the west Dongting area by construction of three reservoirs on the Lishui Basin including Jiangya. Of the three, Jiangya would give the largest incremental gains in flood protection; flood routing simulations show that with Jiangya Dam, flooding of polder areas could have been avoided for nine of the 11 major floods since 1935. For 20-year floods, flooding of polder areas could be eliminated or reduced by about 85 percent (depending on flood volume), and for floods with a 50-year return period, flooding of polders could be reduced by 40 to 50 percent. However, full security against 50-year floods will only be achieved with construction of all three reservoirs on the Li, completion of the Three Gorges Project, and raising of dikes and use of flood detention basins, although floods of short duration can be reasonably controlled by construction of storages in the Li catchment. Three Gorges will have two main benefits in the project area: (a) it will reduce flood discharges in the Yangtze which would allow more rapid drainage of Dongting flood waters to the Yangtze; and (b) it will avoid diversion of Yangtze flows into the Dongting Lake area, except under very exceptional circumstances. This will reduce silting of Dongting Lake and maintain its capacity to handle floods from the Li River. Power Generation 5.14 Jiangya Dam would have an installed capacity of 300 MW, and generate 769 GWh per year on average, of which 640 GWh would be firm (exceeded in 95 percent of years). The project would be linked to the main Hunan Power Grid by 105 km of 220 KV transmission lines; this would be provided for in the power sales agreement (para. 5.20). The annual financial value of power produced based on constant 1994 prices would total some Y 384 million ($44 million). Hunan can well use this additional power. Energy resources in Hunan Province are comparatively poor, with only hydropower resources being relatively abundant, and coal has to be imported. Installed capacity in the Hunan power system is about 50 percent hydropower. About 30 percent of hydropower potential has been developed, and projects under construction would raise this to nearly 50 percent. To meet current electricity demand, the province must import power, with heavy and light industry (including agro-processing) accounting for 76 percent, residential usage for 18 percent, and agriculture only 3 percent. During the 1980's, the growth rate of power generation capacity and energy generation was slow, resulting in a serious shortage of electricity supply in the province. However, during 1991 and 1992, energy generation grew by more than 20 percent.
 - 48 - C. Cosr RECovERY Irrigation and Drainage Subprojects 5.15 Policy. State policy for irrigation water supply is that it should be a financially independent and self-sustaining activity. All beneficiaries of water resource projects, including flood protection services, should pay service fees based on the 'user pays" principle. Fees should cover all O&M costs, including provision for depreciation and major repairs. Payment may be either in cash or paddy. Fees calculated by the relevant irrigation management unit, usually the Irrigation/Drainage Authority or County WRB, should follow Provincial guidelines, and should differentiate between the various users, such as farmers and local municipalities. The official tariff standard for water is volumetric pricing. 5.16 Cost Recovery in Practice. Project Irrigation/Drainage Authorities currently obtain revenues from water charges levied on farmers, sales of untreated M&I water, and from sales of power to the local grid, in addition to revenue from non-water activities. Due to lack of suitable measurement systems, farmers benefiting from irrigation or drainage schemes are normally charged on the basis of area cultivated rather than on volume of water delivered, although the legal formula for calculating water charges includes both fixed (area/crop) and variable (volumetric) components, based on rice prices. The actual rates charged vary from scheme to scheme and are largely decided on the basis of what is considered a tolerable charge rather than actual O&M costs. The charges are collected from farmers by the leaders of the Village Water Management Groups and passed to the Township and County FBs; collection rates are high with few defaults. Funds collected are then passed on to government agencies responsible for O&M, with part being diverted into general budgetary resources at county or township level. In general, only about 45-50 percent of all charges is actually available for actual O&M of the system; of the remainder, about 20 percent of the charges is abstracted directly by the Township and County FBs, and 25-30 percent goes to the Project Management Authority. Water charges are perceived by farmers as a tax similar to other taxes and levies collected by the township and county governments, rather than payment for a service. In addition to charges levied, each farm-household is also required to provide 15-20 days annually of customary, unpaid (corvee) labor for the maintenance or construction of agency-managed infrastructure. The customary labor is controlled, mobilized and used by local governments. 5.17 Water charge rates are relatively low. In Hunan and Hubei charges range around Y 6/mu ($10/ha). However, if the value of the corvee labor required from farmers for system maintenance is also taken into account, the amount paid is about Y 30 per mu ($50/ha), which is not low. For comparison, agricultural incomes in the various subproject areas are Y 200-300/mu ($340- 510/ha). Analysis of charges and costs of O&M shows that although the total amount paid by farmers (cash plus labor) is generally adequate for routine O&M, provided it is efficiently used, it is not usually sufficient to cover periodic repairs and overhaul and certainly not rehabilitation or capital costs. Moreover, the cash clement does not cover salaries plus costs of inputs, such as machinery services or cement,
 - 49 - which have to be purchased. In the case of M&I water, charges are set on the basis of quantity supplied and rates are about 5-10 times the rate set for irrigation water. Funds are directly collected by the Project Management Authority, as are revenues from sale of electricity. 5.18 Cost Recovery Under the Project. Adequate arrangements for cost recovery are essential for the success of SIDDs and the financial viability of WSCs and WUAs, and one of the critical requirements will be to convert the water charge system from a 'tax" to a "service fee" basis. Under the project, cost recovery from farmers for irrigation and drainage subprojects would be partly through direct labor contribution for construction, maintenance and repairs, and partly through water service fees. The farmers' direct contribution of labor during construction, totalling as much as 15-30 percent or more of capital costs, would count against their required corvee labor, part or all of which would be transferred to the WSCs and WUAs for use in construction and O&M of their subprojects (see para. 4.11) and considered as (part of) the farmers' contribution to cost recovery. Financially sustainable water charge rates for O&M would be somewhat higher than current levels in total, and the cash portion of the charges would likely be substantially higher than at present. Analysis of incremental income from project investments indicates that the farmers' ability to pay is adequate (see Annex 6). 5.19 Water charges (service fees) would be collected by WUAs from their members; part would be used to purchase water from the WSC, and part would be retained for intemal WUA operations. Fees paid by WUAs to WSCs for water deliveries would be expected to cover at least full O&M costs of the WSC (allowing for the value of customary labor) and part or all of the repayment cost of the subloan for the World Bank loan. To determine suitable water fee rates, Hubei and Hunan would undertake a study of financial requirements for SIDDs, to make WSCs and WUAs as self-financing as possible. The study would include: analysis of costs of O&M and extraordinary repairs; capital cost recovery: options to reduce costs of O&M; alternative financing terms for capital costs; breakdown of costs between WSCs and WUAs; farmers ability and willingness to pay; arrangements for assignment of farmers' customary labor from local government to WSCs/WUAs; the current level of budget support provided by the government for irrigation and drainage districts (including each subproject area in Hubei); possible budget support/subsidies required in the future (including those needed to compensate for low grain prices); changes needed in water charge regulations and policies (including changes needed to enable WUAs to collect water charges); and recommendations. Policy and budget (financial) support should be continued at current levels in the near term, to avoid discrimination against farmer's who participate in the SIDDs compared to farmers outside the project areas and to maintain incentives to participate; they would be phased out gradually. D. ENVIONMENT AN HEALTH 5.22 The project is classified as an 'A' project by the Bank largely because of the inclusion of the Jiangya Dam and the related resettlement of people living in the area. Environmental impacts of Jiangya would be monitored and controlled through the Jiangya EMMP. The irrigation and drainage subprojects would not have any major adverse environmental effects. Although there may be an increase in fertilizer and pesticide use as a result of more intensive irrigated production, this would be offset to some extent by the soil improvement program which would reduce the use of nitrogenous chemical fertilizers in the farming system due to better balance between nutrients. The non-water subprojects, particularly forestry and grasslands, would have a significant beneficial impact on soil erosion and conservation. Jiangya Dam would provide general improvements in protection of human lives from floods, and the project is also expected to have specific positive health impacts, especially in the Sihu area. Better drainage and water control would reduce malaria breeding areas, and construction methods proposed in the EIA and EMMP would help control schistosomiasis by using dredge spoil to fill low-lying areas where snails breed. In addition, the EMMP for Sihu would promote better long-run environmental management in the area.

Jiangya Dam Subproject 6.6 Flood Control. Flood control benefits were calculated as the reduction in expected average annual flood damage due to operation of Jiangya Dam. Underlying estimates of expected average annual flood damage were made separately for polder areas (below Sanjiankou) and river valley areas (above Sanjiankou). Damages include personal and public property, and lost agricultural and industrial production. Benefits would accrue to the polder areas near Dongting Lake where an estimated 63,667 ha would be protected partially or completely, and in the river valley areas where some 13,333 ha would be partly or completely protected, according to flood frequencies; an estimated 500,000 people would receive some protection. 6.7 Power Generation. Power benefits from Jiangya were calculated by development of least cost expansion plans for the Hunan Power Grid with and without Jiangya. The present value of all capital and operating costs, without including the Jiangya cost, was then calculated for each expansion scenario. The difference in present values provides a measure of alternative cost. If it can be demonstrated that consumers are willing to pay at least this alternative cost, it provides a lower bound estimate of the power supply benefits of Jiangya. Since power from all new thermal power plants in China is priced to achieve loan repayment (assuming fully debt financed) over a ten year period, resulting prices to the grid are substantially above long run marginal cost. All incremental consumption beyond 1983 levels is charged at this 'new" price so there is ample evidence that consumers' willingness to pay is well above long run marginal cost based on thermal generation. The "alternative cost" based on thermal generation therefore provides a lower bound estimate of power benefits. 6.8 In developing least cost expansion plans, it was found that it is economical to develop available hydropower candidates (other than Jiangya) at the earliest possible opportunity. They are therefore common to both scenarios. The replacement for Jiangya in the alternative expansion plan is thermal capacity. Thermal candidates included were
 - 54 - 300 MW and 600 MW coal fired plants, 100 MW distilate fired combined cycle plants, and 10 MW distilate fired gas turbines. Currently, in China, local manufacturers are capable of meeting only 70 percent of the demand for new generating capacity. The remainder is imported. Therefore, import parity prices were used for capital costs of thermal generation. Coal for future large thermal plants in Hunan is likely to come from Shanxi. The shadow price used for coal was based on the export price at Qinhuangdao seaport ($35 per ton at 6,000 k cal./kg). Transportation costs between Shanxi mine mouth and Qinhuangdao were deducted to obtain a mine-mouth export parity price. Rail transport costs between the mine-mouth and Hunan were added to obtain the shadow price in Hunan. 6.9 Cost Allocation. Common costs of the project (dam, flood handling and boatlift facilities) are allocated to power and flood control using the 'separable costs/remaining benefits' methodology. This results in 49 percent of common costs allocated to power and 51 percent allocated to flood control. Project Risks 6.10 There are few technical and institutional risks. Irrigation and drainage subprojects are based on years of successful Chinese and Bank Group experience with similar projects, and nonwater subprojects in Hubei are based on proven technologies and incorporate lessons from similar Bank projects in their design. Jiangya Dam presents several key risks. RCC technology used for Jiangya is relatively new, and Jiangya will be among the highest dams of its type in the world when complete. However, China is a world leader in the use of RCC technology for such dams, and has successfully used RCC technology extensively. The most critical risk is likely to be the supply of cement and fly ash, which must be continuous; the ICB contractor would bear this risk. Availability and timing of counterpart funding is also a significant risk for Jiangya Dam; delays due to lack of funds could be very costly. Financial requirements for Jiangya are very large and concentrated in the early years due to rapid implementation, and shortages of counterpart funding could substantially slow implementation and delay benefits. The financial risk has been addressed by providing a high disbursement percentage for the ICB contract for the Jiangya Dam body, to help ensure that the primary investment is completed on schedule; and by requiring certification that the People's Construction Bank would provide $44 million of local funding for Jiangya as a condition of negotiations (see para. 3.37). There is also a management risk for Jiangya, given that LHPC is newly formed and not yet fully staffed. The project would provide special international TA for Jiangya implementation support, as well as direct institutional development support for LHPC, the latter for both Jiangya and to promote the future role of LHPC in Lishui River Basin management. 6.11 The other substantial risks are associated with the institutional innovations for SIDDs, which would take over responsibility for O&M of irrigation subprojects, and the role of LHPC in Lishui River Basin management. Consequently, these innovations would be pilot tested, phased in gradually and supported by a comprehensive capacity building program. Failure of these institutional innovations will not jeopardize the viability or sustainability of the project, as existing management systems could be retained.

The main objectives of this subcomponent are to increase agricultural production and farmers' income and reduce the risk and impact of floods. Criteria for the selection of subproject areas have been established as follows: (a) areas where farmers' standard of living is very low (poor areas); (b) areas with water shortages and frequent droughts; (c) areas with land of good development potential; (d) areas where existing water conservancy facilities are weak; (e) areas prone to waterlogging and flood risks; and (f) areas where local counterpart funds can be raised. 3. Based on these criteria, four irrigation subprojects (Dongfeng, Zhanghe, Yindan and Wenxia), and one drainage and flood control subproject (Sihu) were selected in the hinterland of the Jianghan and the hilly area between the Yangtze River (Chang Jiang) and the Han River (Han Jiang).
