 - 83 - ANNEX 2 HUBEI NONWATER RESOURCE SUBPROJECTS AND AGRICULTURE ASPECTS A. AQuAcULTuRE SuEPRoJECr Objective 1. The objective of the aquaculture component is to improve aquaculture production in 24 counties/cites in Hubei through increasing fish production in open waters. Works Description 2. The works under this subproject would include aquaculture development of about 12,600 ha in open water, comprised of 17 shallow lakes and reservoirs (some of which are seasonal) and farm ponds. Pond development would include the improvement of 235 ha of nursery ponds and 365 ha of production ponds, and new construction of 151 ha and 215 ha of nursery and production ponds, respectively, of the same sizes noted above for each. The subproject would also finance the construction of five fish hatcheries, one 4.2-ha turtle hatchery, one 1-ha turtle farm, and one 1,000 e2 Technical Service and Extension Center (TSEC). 3. In addition, the project would finance project management and technical assistance (domestic and intemational training, study tours, and consultants) and the formulation of a nongovemmental Hubei Province Fish Farmers' Association. Flsh Production Technology 4. The subproject would support fish production technology in the following areas: (a) Open-Water Flsheries. This would include improving fisheries in 17 selected small lakes/reservoirs. To increase production, each selected water area would be stocked with fish, turtle, and/or crab seed based on the estimated natural productivity of the site for the various species. [Common carp (Cyprinus carplo), bighead carp (Arisdcthys nobilis), silver carp (Hypophthalmichthys molitrix), grass carp (Ctenopharyngodon idellus), Wuchang fish (Megalobrama amblycephala), crucian carp (Cawsius auratus), mandarin fish (Sinapercus chautsi), softshell turtles (honyx sinensis), and river crabs (Eriocheir sinensis).]
 - 84 - ANNEX 2 (b) Filngerling Ponds. The management of new and improved fingerling ponds proposed would follow the best technological practices employed in Hubei. The major species that would be cultured include grass carp, silver carp, bighead carp, common carp, wuchang fish, and crucian carp. (c) Production Ponds. The improved and new production fishponds would be similar to that of the fingerling ponds except they would each cover an area of 0.67 ha and have a total depth of about 3 m and operating water depth of 2.5 m. The same fish species in polyculture would be reared in production ponds as would be in the fingerling ponds. (d) Turtle Ponds. One hectare of eight turtle grow-out ponds would be constructed as a pilot scheme at Baishuitan Fish Farm in Shashi County. One of the eight 0.125 ha ponds would be used to rear turdes from 50 g to 100 g, after which they would be transferred to the other seven ponds for grow-out to 500 g market-sized turtles. The grow-out areas would include pond and land areas for the turtles. (e) Flsh Hatcheries. Five standard fish hatcheries used for the production of Chinese major carp (primarily grass, silver, and bighead carps) would be built at five farms in five separate counties/cities. (f) Turtle Hatchery. A 4.2-ha, softshell turtle hatchery would be constructed under the project. Support Activities 5. Technical Service and Extension Center (TSEC). The subproject would include the construction of a 1,000 e2 center that would include a fish disease clinic, offices and a classroom for extension officers, and the headquarters of the Hubei Fish Farmers' Association discussed below. 6. Hubei Province Fish Farmers' Association (FFA). The objective of the nongovernmental HFFA would be to establish a membership organization that would be a direct means within the province for fish farmers to exchange information on their experience, be provided with market intelligence, and direct and finance practical research on specific problems facing fish farmers in Hubei. 7. Technical Assistance, Study Tours and Training. The project would include a comprehensive domestic and international training program, including training for fishermen, fish farmers, fish and turtle hatchery operators, and turtle farmers benefited by the project. 8. Research. Research would be conducted on project-related aspects of lake/ reservoir fishery management (aquatic ecology, fishing strategies,and use of feed and
 - 85 - ANNE 2 fertilizer inputs) and aquaculture (propagation of high-valued species, feed for these species, and fish disease prevention). Organization and Management 9. The Hubei Fishery Project Management Office (FPMO) of the Province Fishery Bureau would have overall responsibility for implementing the aquaculture component. The FPMO would be assisted in construction supervision by counterpart offices established in the respective prefecture and county/city Fishery Bureaus. Inplementation and Procurement 10. The aquaculture subproject would be developed over a five-year period with eight specific project units to be initiated in the first year, nine in the second year, and seven in the third year. All site development works would be procured through local competitive bidding (LCB) procedures satisfactory to the Bank. Water Resources Bureaus at the Provincial, and city/county, levels would review and approve design and specifications and would certify completion of construction of engineering works. Works completed through force account would be required to follow the regulations established for the overall project for force account. The purchase of equipment should also follow the Bank procurement guidelines. Production and Markets 11. Production. At full development, the total estimated incremental gross revenue from the aquaculture component would be about Y 72 million per year. 12. Markets. There is a well-established fish marketing system in Hubei. From previous statistics, the marketing of the fish produced by the project should not be a problem; fish consumption in Hubei has been increasing at a rate in excess of the anticipated production from the project at full development and is expected to continue to do so. There also appears to be sufficient market demand outside Hubei should surplus fish from the project be available. Environmental Aspects 13. The fish populations play an important role in the ecological function of open waters, and the project would help to support fish diversity and production through developing a strategic management strategy to meet the specific characteristics of each individual lake/reservoir. The proposed new pond construction would be developed in fallow areas prone to fostering waterborne diseases (e.g., malaria) and that are generally waterlogged, saline, and/or alaline. Pond development would diminish the warborne public health hazards by reducing the habitats for the disease vectors. Analyses of source water quality at all project sites were found to be within Chinese national standards for fisheries (GB11607-89) for each pollutant, independently. However, at some project sites, heavy metal and pesticide pollution was detected for more than one pollutant, the
 - 86 - ANNEX 2 cumulative effect of which might pose some problems. The water quality at sites (Jianli, Yichang, Shashi, Jinmeng, and Xiantao) of concern should be monitored annualy, and fish vitality and condition should be observed for any possible effects each year as well. Role of Women 14. The project would provide additional employment opportunities for women in the project areas. It is envisioned that about 30 percent of the new fingerling and production ponds, turtle ponds, turtle hatchery, and fish hatcheries would be contracted to female heads of households. The other aquaculture subcomponents would either be enhancing open-water fisheries for which there is already an established community of fishers, or improving existing ponds that are already contracted to households. Beneficiaries 15. The project would benefit about 1,835 households, comprised of 460 fishers (1 per 27 ha), 1,340 pond contractors (1 per 0.67 ha), 6 turtle hatchery operators, 25 fish hatchery contractors (5 per hatchery), and 4 turtle pond contractors (1 per 0.25 ha). Project Cost and FSnancing 16. The total cost estimate for the aquaculture component would be about Y 127 milion ($14.6 million), of which approximately Y 25.4 million ($2.9 million) would be allocated for working capital. Approximately 50 percent of the cost would be provided as a loan from the World Bank, 20 percent as loans from provincial resources, 15 percent as loans from prefecture and county/city resources, and 15 percent contributed from the benefiting fish farms in the form of labor, equipment, materials, and cash. B. AGRiCULTu SupROJEcrs Introduction 17. The nonwater watershed protection components comprise activities in forestry development, livestock grassland development, and soil improvement for building a small fertilizer industry that would support forestry and grasslands activities and those of the irrigation districts. 18. The subproject areas are located in a total of 23 different counties of Hubei and include both irrigated and upland areas. The individual subcomponent locations include forestry development in 11 counties), soil improvement in 23 counties, and livestock/grassland development in 21 counties. 19. The lowland areas are generally under intensive cultivation, following a rice/ cotton-wheat/rape rotatiom and including a range of other crops such as peanut, soybean, maize, tubers and vegetables. Protection forestry in the lowlands is located along stream, river and canal banks. Upland areas vary from moderately fertile yellow and red soils in
 - 87 - ANNEX 2 undulating areas with slopes of approximately 8 to 15 degrees to acid, eroded, infertile red soils on hills of 25 or more degrees of slope. 20. Irrigated area productivity is limited by recurring drought in late summer, by relatively dry winters and also by unbalanced ferdlizer applications, particularly inadequate supplies of (largely imported) potassium ferilizers. 21. Uplands are, on average, moderately eroded over 10 to 20 percent of their total area. Deforestation and cropping of slopes above 20 degrees has created localized areas of very severe erosion. The whole upland area, moreover, suffers from frequent poverty as a result of low cultivated areas per household (commonly less than 0.25 ha), low soil fertility, and low productivity. 22. The forestry and livestock/grassland development subprojects are located in more marginal areas of the lowlands and in the uplands. They are intended to both directly protect areas such as stream and canal banks and eroded hillsides (forestry subcomponent) and to further develop technology for the protection and economic development of lower slopes and marginal sites along rivers (livestock/Grassland Development Subproject). Organization and Management 23. Each subproject would be implemented by their respective line agencies-the Forestry Bureau, Livestock and Animal Husbandry Bureau, and Agriculture and Animal Husbandry Department. A section (soil improvement, water conservation, forestry or livestock/grasslands) of a Project Office that would work with a Project Leading Group at the county/city level and respond to the Project Management Office at the Provincial level is the line agency concerned. The Provincial Project Office would report to the Provincial Leading Group. Forestry Subproject 24. This subproject aims to restore forest cover in watersheds above the main irrigation areas, improve the quality of technical services in forestry and improve incomes of farm households. The households would include those involved directly in the irrigation developments through protection forestry on irrigation works and those in upland areas away from irrigation development through protection, timber and economic forestry development. 25. The Forestry Subproject is oriented toward an agroforestry and farm systems approach involving intercropping for the first five to eight years on about 68 percent of the planted area, depending on the tree crop involved and its probable growth rate. 26. Soil conservation within the subproject would utilize, where possible, vegetative rather than traditional structural soil conservation measures such as terracing. Lower slopes would be intercropped while steeper areas would be used for protection or
 - 88 - ANNEX 2 timber forestry, with no cultivation of existing vegetative cover. Economic forest would be planted on the contour. 27. Subproject Location. The project would be implemented in 11 counties on the Jianghan Plain (Jiangling, Songzhi, Xiaogan, Yuenmong, and Zhijiang counties) and North Hubei hillock area (Laohekou, Xiangyang, Zhaoyang, Suizhou, Yingchen and Zhongxiang counties) along the Yangtze and Han rivers. 28. Subproject Description. The proposed development would comprise three main types of plantings: (a) Economic Forest. A total of 5,718 ha would be planted to peach/plum and pear (1,705 ha), citrus (200 ha), chestnut (3,013 ha), Chinese wolfoerry (lycium chinense, 200 ha), eucomia (Eucomia ulmoides, 200 ha) and tea (400 ha); (b) Timber Forest. A total of 5,000 ha on more marginal sites in both the uplands and lowlands would be planted to poplar (Populus deltoides and Populus xueranicana, 1,000 ha) and slash pine (Pinus elliotii and Pinus taeda, 4,000 ha), principally for pulpwood production and poles; and (c) Protection Forest. Steep slopes and river and canal banks over an area of 6,000 ha would be protected using plantations of water and pond fir (Metaseqoia gIyptostroboides and Taxodiwn ascendens spp, 1,000 ha), slash pine (Pinus eUiouii and Pinus taeda, 2,000 ha) and Italian poplar (Populus deltoides and Populus xueranicana, 3,000 ha). 29. In addition, the subproject would also include construction/expansion of training center, forestry establishment, and institution-building including support for vehicles/equipment, technical assistance and study tours, training and extension, research and management. 30. Quantities of compound NP ferdlizer to be applied to trees during the establishment period, particularly in year 2, would provide a progressive increase in application with increases in tree volume over time. Some NP fertilizer would be applied (at half rates compared to timber forestry) to the slash pine protection forestry, in view of proven cost-benefit ratios of 30 to 1 for ferilizer on timber (slash pine) forestry. 31. Costs for the Forestry Subproject are shown in Table 1. The costs of increased fertlizer application are balanced in part by reduced expenditure on seedlings. All seedlings to be used would be first class. Planting standards for seedlings are shown in Table 2. 32. The timber and fruit yield increases of crops where adequate fertlizer and first-class seedlings at correct densities are used should be considerable. Current yields
 - 89 - ANNEX 2 of peach and plum, for example, are about 4 tons per hectare compared to yields of 15 to 20 tons in more advanced areas of China. 33. Project activities in protection forestry would protect 31 small- and medium- size reservoirs, 128 km of main and branch irrigation canals and 109 km of river bank. Border plantings would protect 21,500 ha of agricultural land. Timber forest output would increase by about 843,000 m3 at year 20. 34. The project would involve about 20,828 farm households in the development of 14,863 ha, of which 83 percent is currently under collective management and 6.1 percent is under the household responsibility system. The areas per household for each county and forest type are given in Table 4. In general, protection forestry households have the largest land areas (average 1 ha), reflecting lower returns per hectare, followed by timber forest( 0.9 ha) and economic forest households (0.6 ha). The developments would also involve 1,855 ha of state forestland, accounting for 11 percent of the development area. 35. Research, Extension and Training. The project would require investment in research to support both the increases in yield needed for economic justification and the process of change from block forestry to an agroforestry approach. The research investments are summarized in Table 1. Grasslands Subproject 36. Rationale and Approach. This subproject would support development of grasslands for steer fattening over 19,525 ha of marginal uplands and lowlands (11,415 ha in the uplands and 8,110 ha in the lowlands). The project is based on household fattening of store cattle from mountain breeding areas. An annual turnover of some 42,000 head of cattle is planned at full development. 37. Project Location. The subproject would be located in 11 lowland and 10 upland counties on the Jiangyan plain and the nearby foothill areas. A summary of investments for the individual counties participating in the project is given in Table 7. The project would also support improvements to the Provincial Livestock Breeding Station in Wuhan. The subproject would include activities in upland and lowland grassland development (including drainage and irrigation of lowlands), infrastructure construction, breeding center redevelopment, research, training, extension, study tours and consultancy. A summary of project costs is given in Table 3. 38. Project Description. The project would develop grasslands from wastelands currently under the direct control of townships or within existing county breeding farms owned by city administrations. In either case, the basis of development would be the household responsibility system, with contracts for farm development taken out under inheritable user rights for a minimum 50-year period.
 - 90 - ANNEX 2 39. The areas to be developed are currently unsuitable for arable agriculture, because of either soil infertility and periodic drought (upland areas) or periodic waterlogging (lowlands). A project risk is that measures such as dams being built in the lowlands will, in combination with drainage and irrigation investment under the subproject, make the lowland areas more attractive to high-value cropping and result in conversion of pastures to cropping. 40. The following are the main investments that would be financed under the project: (a) Grassland Development. The project would settle some 14,018 households from surrounding areas on farms of 1 ha (lowlands) or 2 ha (upland). In view of the different yield potentials in each area, upland households would fatten three cattle on 2 ha per year from a yield of 6,000 kg/ha of ryegrass/ red clover (Loliwn perenne)/(trifolium pratense) dry matter, whereas lowland households would fatten three cattle per hectare on irrigated grasslands producing 12,000 kg/ha of ryegrass/white clover (trifolium repens) dry matter. Soils would be improved with an initial application of 400 kg of 15:15:15 compound fertilizer and adequate annual dressings of superphosphates (375 kg/ha) and nitrogen as urea (150 kg/ha). An initial dressing of 5 kg/ha zinc, 2 kg/ha boric acid and 0.5 kg sodium molybdate would correct micronutrient deficiencies. (b) Individual households would purchase cattle store stock at a weight of about 100 kg from the surplus stock available from herds in surrounding mountain areas toward the end of winter each year. These store stock would be fattened for about 12 months, to be sold at the time of the succeeding spring festival. Breeding stock in surrounding hill and mountain areas would be improved under assistance to the Provincial livestock breeding center. No sheep would be included in the project (as originally planned) owing to very low returns from lamb production. (c) Silage and Hay Storage. To support livestock production on an annual basis, given the harsh winters and late summer drought of the area, the subproject would develop about 3.75 m3 (lowland areas) or 4.5 m3 (upland areas) of silage pits per ha of grassland developed and construct about 2.7 m2 (lowlands) or 3 m2 (uplands) of hay storage per ha developed. The lowlands would be either drained (Sihu area) or irrigated with a total of 46 km of canals. Silage and hay storage are based on the requirement for about 45 days feeding in late winter of an average 250 kg animal. The early winter requirements would be met from hay stored in temporary haystacks and later ammoniated with urea, if necessary, according to quality. The livestock requirements are based on fattening of three 100 kg animals to 400 kg per household per year.

 - 101 - ANEX 3 JIANGYA MULTIPURPOSE DAM SUBPROJECT Background 1. Subproject Objectives. The primary objective of the subproject is for control of floods and supply of power to the northern Hunan region. Less substantial benefits will also result from a more reliable water supply for irrigation and domestic uses, and from improved river transportation. 2. Currently, flooding in the Songli District is frequent and serious, as experienced during the major flood disasters that occurred in 1935 and 1954. In 1935 the flood inundated over 78,000 ha of agricultural lands and affected a population of 1.44 million, with more than 33,000 lives lost. In 1954, almost all of the protective dikes were breached, agricultural area flooded reached 55,400 ha and a population of 783,000 was affected. Very serious flooding also occurred in 1964, 1980, 1983 and 1991. Even after massive work in raising and strengthening dikes, the current flood protection standard is estimated at holding back floods of a return interval of only four to seven years. These production levels are deteriorating because of sedimentation in the lake area, primarily originating from diversion of high flows in the Yangtze to Dongting Lake. 3. The overall river basin plan for the Li River envisions the construction of 26 storage facilities: 17 on the Li River itself, and 9 on the main tributaries (4 on the Lou and 5 on the Xi). The full implementation of the plan would provide a total reservoir capacity of 11.835 billion m3, of which 2.566 billion m3 will be reserved for flood control. In the long term, with provision of facilities of the full plan's flood storage capacity, the construction of Three Gorges Project, integrated with raising of dikes and use of flood detention basins, it is anticipated that security can be provided against floods of a 50-year return period. 4. For the short term, protection against 20-year floods could be provided by construction of three reservoirs on the Li and its two main tributaries (iangya on the Lou with flood storage of 0.75 billion e3, Zaoshi on the Xieshui with flood storage of 0.78 billion m3, and Yichongqiao on the Li with flood storage of 0.25 billion e3. With construction of Jiangya and these three reservoirs, areas above Sanjiankoiu would be protected against 50-year floods, while areas below Sanjianlkou the protecdon level would only be for the 20-year or smaller floods. Of the three primary flood control reservoirs, Jiangya makes the largest impact, because of the amount of catchment controlled and the more severe flooding characteristics of the Lou River. It has therefore been selected as the first priority for implementation.
 - 102 - ANNEX 3 5. In addition to the flood problems, the energy resources in Hunan Province are comparatively poor, with only the potential for hydropower resources being relatively abundant. While Hunan has some coal resources, which continue to be exploited, Hunan still must import coal from other provinces to supplement its own resources. Generation expansion plans call for all coal for future large-scale power generation to be imported. Exploitable hydro resources are estimated at 12.43 GW and 50.9 TWh, and at the end of 1992, 29.6 percent of total estimated capacity had been developed. Projects under construction would raise this level to almost 50 percent. Installed capacity in the Hunan Power System at end of 1992, was 6,523 MW, of which 49.2 percent was hydro. 6. The Jiangya Project is designed to have an installed capacity of 300 MW, and it is estimated that it will generate 790 GWh per year on average, of which 640 GWh is considered to be firm (exceeded in 95 percent of years). The power facilities will be linked to the main Hunan Provincial Grid by 220 kV transmission lines. Subproject Area 7. Location and Setting. The Li River originates in mountainous country and is joined by two main tributaries, the Lou and the Xie rivers, before flowing into a low- lying lakelplains area (the Songli District) just downstream of Sanjiankou. The river morphology in the lake area is extremely complicated. The Li River, after Sanjiankou, flows into west Dongting Lake, which is connected to the Yangtze River. In this lake region, agricultural and populated areas are situated in 'polder' areas proteced by 531 km of dikes. 8. Climate. The climate of the Loushui River is classified as subtropical monsoon, characterized by warm and humid conditions. The mean annual precipitation is 1,650 mm, with 69 percent occurring in the months from April to August. The high rainfall can be attributed to the location of the catchment at the junction of cold air masses and warm air masses with active frontal movement, and the orographic effect due to the orientation of the mountain ridges with respect to the northern direction of warm air flow. Furthermore, the catchment is on the track of frequent cyclones. At the Cili meteorological station, mean annual surface temperature is 18.5C, and mean annual relative humidity is 78 percent. Storms occur throughout the rainy season but are most severe in June and July. Storm tracks tend to parallel flow direction and generally have high intensity, long duration and wide coverage. The most severe storm near the catchment area occurred in July 1935 and was located in Wufeng County in Hubei Province. The five-day precipitation recorded in the County reached 1,288 mm. 9. Hydrology. There are 11 river gauging stations on the Loushui River, four with periods of records longer than 30 years. With such long periods of good overlapping data, effective correlations between the series were achieved and a reliable 40-year monthly runoff series for the dam site was synthesized for use in the designs. The mean annual runoff volume at the dam site is 4.16 billion m3 (see Table 1) with recorded annual variance ranging from a low to high of 2.68 and 7.0 billion i3, respectively. On average, 72 percent of runoff volume occurs between April and August.
 - 103 - ANNEX 3 10. Floods have been recorded in historical documents since the 15th century. The flood of July 1935 is the most extreme observed in the last 132 years. It was actually centered over a nearby catchment area, about 50 km from the Jiangya catchment center. The area rainfalls for 24- and 72-hour duration were the largest recorded in China and close to the envelope of world maxima. The peak flow of the flood with 5,000-year return period is estimated at 15,700 m3/sec and the thee-day runoff exceeds 2 billion mi. The design of the dam should take such overtopping into account. 11. Flood frequency analyses were also made for four periods of five and six months during the winter season between September and March. The analyses are of particular interest to determine the risks of overtopping of the upstream cofferdam and flooding of the construction site during winter. The results summarized in Table 3 show that if, for example, the diversion tunnel has a maximum capacity of 2,000 m3 the risk of overtopping is one in five years between September and March, and only one in 20 years between October and March. The cofferdam would usually be overtopped at least once during the rainy season. 12. The mean annual sediment volume at the dam site is estimated at 1.68 million tons, of which over 95 percent occurs during the flood season April to November, with 36 percent during the month of July. The local average silt content (0.4 gr/liter) can be explained by the widespread exposure of the limestone and other rock formations upstream of the dam. 13. Geology and Seismology. Geologic investigation and exploration for Jiangya Dam and reservoir area, which commenced in 1979, continued intermittently through 1992 and included: (a) geologic mapping from 1 in 50,000, to 1 in 500; (b) core drilling-15,952 m in 159 holes;
 -104 - ANNEX 3 (c) auger drilling-186 m in 54 holes; (d) exploration adits-3,875 m in 78 drives; (e) two exploration shafts-26 m; (f) 7,858 m3 of test pits; and (g) a wide range of in-situ and laboratory, mechanical, chemical and geophysical testing. 14. The geologic structure of the reservoir area is relatively simple, embracing a series of folds, with a general NNE-SSW orientation. The river cuts transversely across a series of anticlines and synclines. Sandstones and shales of the Silurian and Devonian systems alternate with carbonate formations of the Permian and Triassic systems. The only major seismically active fault in the region is the Cili-Dayong fault located about 35 km away from the dam site. An earthquake of magnitude 5.0 occurred in 1986 in Dayong and, according to historical records, several earthquakes of magnitude less than 3.5 have occurred. According to a regional study carried out by the Geological Research Institute, the area of the dam site belongs in the category of low seismicity. The most important geological considerations in the reservoir is the stability of an old landslide about 1 km upstream of the dam site. 15. The Miaozui landslide, located 1 km upstream of the dam site has been the object of special investigations as the original sliding mass was estimated to have a total volume of 3.6 million m3 and a thickness of 20 to 85 m. It appears that the slide once blocked the original course of the river, causing it to shift to the right side of the valley. The landslide was found to be stable under present natural conditions. However, it is possible that the slide could be reactivated during the initial filling period or during any rapid lowering of the reservoir level. Experts who have studied the slide are of the opinion that the movements would be small and that the landslide does not present a risk to dam safety. Monitoring of the landslide during construction and impounding has been recommended. 16. The river valley at the dam site is relatively symmetrical with slopes of 40 to 450 on the left bank and slightly steeper on the right bank. The valley is 280 m wide at the reservoir level of 236 m above sea level. The dam site is situated on the southeast slope of the wide Liuzhiping anticline. The rock formation dips 30 to 45 downstream, nearly normal, to the river course. The strata exposed at the dam site from upstream to downstream are sandstone and shale intercalations, giving way to limestone at the upstream end. The dam body will be built on the lower Permian limestone rock formations, which are sound, with shallow weathering and high mechanical strength. Although a total of 19 minor faults were found in the dam site area, they are mostly compression and sheer faults of relatively short length, with fractured zones of up to 1 m and offsets of 2 to 3 m. The largest fault in the dam area is 350 m long, with offset of about 3 m. Filling of the
 - 105 - ANNEX 3 faults is not well cemented and karst voids have developed. The intensity of joints and fissures in the dam site area is low. 17. The hydrogeology of the site, especially the presence of a hot-water aquifer, is an important consideration for the design of the dam and treatment of its foundations. The hot aquifer is 70 to 90 m deep underneath the dam foundations and outcrops upstream of the dam axis in the deepest area of the reservoir. 18. Construction Materials. There are eight quarries within 15 km downstream of the dam site, and reserves are estimated at about 3.8 million m3 and gravel material is 2.9 million m3. The quality of these materials meet the demands of the design. Limestone suitable for aggregate is abundant in quantity downstream of the dam site. A quarry site on the right bank of the Loushui River located in a small hill at the exit of the Jiangya gorge, some 5 km away from the dam site was selected after investigation, to be reserved for the contractor's use. The quarry is characterized by good quality, and little topsoil. Description of Subproject Works 19. River Diversion Facilities. Because of the tendency of the river to produce intense flooding, and since concrete dams under construction can endure overtopping without large losses, the diversion tunnel has been designed to pass dry-season floods only. The tunnel will be 550 m long with a cross section of 10 m x 12 m. Both upstream and downstream cofferdams are to be RCC and are also capable of being overtopped without serious damage. The final crest elevations of upstream and downstream cofferdams are, respectively, 153 m and 138 m. The upstream cofferdam will be constructed to an initial 138 m elevation for the first flood season to match with the resettlement program and then raised to the full height prior to the second season. The diversion tunnel will be capable of passing 1,500 m3/sec, which is equivalent to a 1 in 10-year flood during the months of October to April. However during the rainy season (May-September), flood frequency analysis shows that the cofferdam will be overtopped at least once a year. 20. Main Dam. Taking into account the topography and geology of the most suitable dam sites over an 11 km reach of the river and of availability of construction materials, a feasibility study was performed to compare five alternatives consisting of RCC gravity dam, RCC gravity arch dam, hollow-gravity dam and combinations of these types. As a result of these studies, an RCC gravity dam at the Shuihuiyao site was recommended and subsequently approved by the General Planning Institute of Water Resources and Hydroelectric Projects and the Planning Department of MWR. The approved layout comprised of an RCC gravity dam, flood-handling facilities consisting of mid-level outlets and surface outlets, right bank powerhouse, with switchyard and inclined shiplift on the left bank. 21. The design is for an RCC gravity dam with crest at El. 242 m, lowest foundation level at El. 242 m, with maximum dam height of 128 m resulting in a crest length of 336 m. The overall concrete volume will be 1.4 million m3. At the time of construction completion, the dam is expected to be one of the world's highest and largest
 -106 - ANNEX 3 volume RCC dams. The total storage capacity is 1.7 billion m3, of which 740 million m3 will be use for flood storage between April and September. 22. The dam will consist of three sections laterally, a central overflow spillway section 86.5 m wide with two higher elevation sections on each abutment. There will be four overflow spillway bays with a crest elevation of 224 m, controlled by radial gates 14 m wide and 12 m high. In addition, there are three middle-level orifice spillway outlets, located below each pier of the overflow bays, with sill level at 190 m, controlled by 5 m wide by 7 m wide radial gates. Flip buckets are arranged at two levels, first for the two center overflow bays discharging at El. 190 m, and also for the outer overflow bays and mid-level outlets discharging at El. 150 m. The two sets of outflow jets are designed to collide with each other resulting in a high levels of energy dissipation prior to entering the riverbed. Flow aeration is provided in orifice spillway inverts downstream of the gates, and in the outer overflow spillway bays at about half height. The slope immediately downstream of the dam will be covered with a heavily reinforced concrete slab anchored to the rock with high-capacity rock anchors, designed to provide confinement of the rock foundation, to guard against back erosion of the foundation below the plunge pool. 23. An irrigation outlet is provided on the left abutment consisting of a pipe through the body of the dam. The 1.1 m diameter pipe will be set at El. 200.3 m, and will have a design discharge of 4.3 m3/sec. It is controlled on the upstream face with a vertical slide gate. 24. The dam body will be constructed using RCC, with high fly ash content. Construction methods are designed to achieve full bonding at lift joints. As far as possible, this will be achieved by continuous placing in 0.3 m lifts such that successive lifts are placed before final set of the concrete. Set retardant admixtures will assist in delaying the set time. Should the surface set up before the next layer is placed, a bedding mix will be required to be applied. The upstream face of the dam will consist of a richer RCC mix designed for a higher strength and lower permeability. There will be contraction joints at lateral intervals with mechanical waterstops. In addition, an impermeable membrane coating will be placed on the exterior of the upstream face to provide an additional water barrier. High-strength concrete with silica power additive will be used for the hydraulic surfaces of the spillway and mid-level outlets. The downstream face of the gravity dam sections will be stepped, which will improve energy dissipation in the event of overtopping of the dam by floods. In addition, downstream valley sides will be concreted to reduce erosion by water released through the spillway. 25. The construction logistics for the nearly continuous placement of the RCC will be very difficult due to the large volumes of cement and fly ash that need to be brought to the site daily over a rather undeveloped regional transportation system. Some storage of these construction materials is planned to be required at the site to allow for minor disruptions in the incoming heavy traffic.

They will consist of vertical tower-type structures, containing bell-mouthed inlets, trashracks, sliding-type maintenance gates, and wheel-mounted emergency gates, each supplying a 6.0 m diameter, 202 m long headrace tunnel. Each tunnel is designed to consist of an initial horizontal section 86 m long at El. 170 m, followed by a 45 degree shaft and a short horizontal section leading to the spiral case inlet. The upper portion of the tunnels will be lined with reinforced concrete, while the inclined shaft and high-pressure tunnel are to be steel lined. 27. The underground powerhouse is located in the right bank, some 85 m downstream of the dam axis, in an area where the rock mass is massive limestone, free of significant faults. The main powerhouse cavern has a span of 21 m and a length of 104 m, including a 32 m erection bay at the right end, and an 18 m long auxiliary bay at the left end. A transformer tunnel, with a 18 m span and 90 m length, will run parallel to the main cavern and is to be located 30 m downstream of it, while a smaller draft tube gate gaUery, 70.5 long with a span of 10 m, will be located 15 m downstream. The 220 kV, 110 kV switchyard will be at the surface approximately 100 m downstream of the powerhouse. There will be two access tunnels to the powerhouse, one from downstream into the erection bay, and the second from the elevator in the right dam abutment into the auxiliary bay of the powerhouse.  - 116 - ANNEX 4 A=endix A Institutional Strengthening 4. The tools and techniques of modem corporate management are still largely unknown -in China at this time. This lack is one of the major constraints on development of the private sector. While it is recognized that the techniques to manage a successful bureaucratic organization differ from those required to manage a successful private corporation, the differences are not sufficiently understood by those who are directly involved in the transition process due to their lack of private sector experience. In China, the traditional bureaucratic management style centers around a requirement to fulfill employment quotas utilizing subsidies when necessary. There is a natural reluctance to recognize that the bureaucratic management style is not only ineffective, it may even be counterproductive in a modem private corporation in which a main objective is return on investment in the context of capital and budgetary constraints. Furthermore, there is essentially no experience with the key prerequisites for effective management: authority, responsibility and accountability. 5. These policies, regulations and procedures differ materially from those in a bureaucracy because of the difference in basic objectives. 6. Financial Planning and Management 8. Proper planning is the key determining element of the success of a corporate operation with the ambitious development objectives of LHPC. A corporate plan has both short- and long-term components that take into consideration all significant requirements of present and future business enterprises. The long-range plan typically covers a 10- to 20-year horizon. Strategic in nature, it establishes the overall direction of the corporation, identifying human, financial and other resources required to achieve targeted growth opportunities for the enterprise. 9. The short-term plan, usually covering a three-year horizon, describes specific activities the corporate management commits to undertake to reach its near-term objectives. The short-term plan is budget-oriented and includes detailed descriptions of specific resources required (staff, organizational, financial and others). It also identifies the specific results (in financial and other terms) expected from the employment of corporate resources. An effective short-term plan also identifies specific management responsibilities for achieving results. It defines the authority provided to each manager required to carry out their responsibilities, and provides the methods for determining accountability for any results achieved. A proper corporate plan thereby provides the Board of Directors and shareholders with an objective means of measuring the performance of management. 10. Corporate management, in turn, measures performance of the organization compared to the short-term plan on a regular basis, usually monthly, and reports such results each quarter to the Board and shareholders. Thus, a well-conceived, realistic, comprehensive plan is the most essential management tool. Generally the focus of most
 - 118 - ANNEX 4 Aygndix A management meetings, the plan is subject to regular updating and revision on a 'rolling' basis such that, at the end of each fiscal year, there should always be a new three-year plan presented to the Board for action. 11. Management Decision Support 12. The ability of key managers to function effectively in a new, rapidly growing company is a direct function of their ability to make informed decisions and to exercise the proper control to achieve the expected results of their decisions. This requires all managers to have access to the specific information to support their decisions at the time the decisions are made. Accurate information should be gathered efficiently, processed quickly and stored safely for quick retrieval. Management reports should be readily available in formats that present decision-oriented information with a minimum of delay so that valuable management time is not lost searching through voluminous files for information. Tools are also needed to facilitate analysis of information either by staff personnel or by managers themselves if they wish to use them. Finally, as an essential element of control, management needs a mechanism to follow up the results of decisions through an efficient system of feedback reporting. 13. Management decision requirements relate to information in the areas of planning, programming and budgeting, finance, accounting, performance measurement,
 - 119 - ANNEX 4 A=ndix A material costs, market prices, environmental considerations, personnel, construction schedules, joint venture evaluation, among others. Management reports generally include (a) comparisons of actual performance versus planned objectives, (b) status of financial conditions, (c) organizational and personnel performance, (d) new business developments, and (e) impact of changes in the environment on the business. Most management reports would be produced by the staff on a regular schedule, but some reports would also need to be produced in response to special demands. The staff responsible for the production of such reports should be well trained in both analytical techniques and in the use of the tools that produce them. 14. Management personnel should be involved in the design and specification of their decision systems. Systems designers are technicians and cannot be expected to have sufficient understanding of the management decision-making processes to enable them to meet all management requirements. Direct involvement of management in the design process is necessary to ensure that the system adequately supports their decision-making requirements. The participatory process that involves management in each step of the system design is often known as 'prototyping" and is faster and less costly to develop and more responsive than traditional system designs. 15. In addition to decision-making, information must also be made available for purposes other than intemal decision-making, such purposes as reporting to govemment authorities, to financial institutions and shareholders. While financial systems usually receive top priority in the development schedule, systems are also useful for planning and budgeting, to manage construction, analyze competing investments, automate office management, modeling, and other analytical purposes. In such instances, thoroughness, accuracy and timeliness of the information is emphasized as is the effectiveness of the report design, distribution and feedback process. 16.  - 127 - ANNEX 4 AXendix D FIANCIAL ANALYSIS Background 1. Power Unit. A 'new power/new price' policy has been applied by the Chinese Government to encourage investment in the power sector since the mid-1980s. Under this policy, tariffs for power supplied by new facilities may be set at levels that achieve a reasonable rate of return to assets. For power projects financed with domestic, nonbudgetary funds, a clearly defined pricing procedure/mechanism was stipulated in government regulations. Policy allowing peak/off-peak price parity was also adopted. However, for projects financed by foreign funds, the regulations only vaguely stipulated that tariffs should be based on costs, taxes and necessary profit. No clear-cut procedures/ mechanism have been defined. 2. Assurance would be obtained from the government that by June 30, 1997, a power sales agreement, acceptable to the Bank, would be signed between LHPC and the Hunan Power Grid. The agreement would establish: (a) The procedure for setting, and periodically adjusting the average tariff for electricity supplied by the Project, to achieve a projected debt-to-service coverage of 1.4-1.5 [as a proxy for a real financial rate of return (FRR) of no less than 10 percent, on the proportion of the project capital and operating costs allocated to power]; and (b) The principles for determining the tariff structure, that is, the proportions of the average tariff that are derived from capacity charges and from energy charges (which may vary according to time of day and season) to ensure efficient dispatch of the power produced by the project, and reduce the financial risk due to volatile hydrological conditions. 3. With regard to the first provision, the proportion of common cost (dam, reservoir, resetdement, etc.) allocated to the Power Unit, using estimated costs and benefits at the date of appraisal, and based on the separable-cost/remaining-benefits cost allocation methodology, is 49.1 percent. 4. The adopted mechanism for tariff determination and adjustment should, as far as possible, maintain a constant power tariff in real terms, eliminating the negative impact of inflation, and providing for a better match between the cash inflows and outflows of LHPC. Acceptable mechanisms would include the debt service coverage ratio method Lpara. 2(a), above].
 - 128 - ANNEX 4 A=endixc D 5. FSnancial Management. To increase financial incentives and accountability, the government has decentralized its management system for the sector. Water conservancy institutions were first asked to adopt business management systems in the early 1980s. Since the late 1980s, they have been allowed to covert into publicly owned corporations whenever conditions permit, and become fully responsible for their financial performance according to the Enterprise Law. This trend of decentralization is further enhanced by the government decision in 1994 to establish a market economy in China. 6. Against this background, LHPC was set up as an independent, publicly owned corporation. It will have the same financial autonomy and accountability as other publicly owned enterprises have under the Enterprise Law. To enhance the financial accountability of LHPC, a profit center would be set up for the hydropower operations, and separate cost accounts would be maintained for the water supply, and flood control operations. Although cross-subsidization is unavoidable for this multipurpose operation because of the very different financial circumstances for the two major operations, the actual revenue and expenses of the accounting units would be clearly separated. The following discusses the performance of the Power Unit in electricity production and sale, and the Reservoir Unit mainly for flood control operations. Revenues from tourism and navigation operations would be negligible, and are omitted from the analysis. 7. Changing Policy Environment. There have been several policy changes that have an important bearing on this analysis. First, in 1989 new guidelines for financial/economic evaluation of hydropower projects were adopted by Ministry of Water Resources and the Ministry of Energy, in which a FRR of 10 percent was selected as the minimum acceptable for a hydropower project. Second, a new accounting system, designed in line with internationally accepted practices, was put into effect July 1, 1993. The new system substantially increased the financial autonomy of the state-owned enterprises. However, implications of the new system for the existing power pricing policy, i.e., the 'new power/new price' policy, is still unknown, as details of the system are still being formulated. Another important accounting change is formulation of regulations for assets revaluation in the water resources and power sectors. These are already being tested in some of the large grids of the power sector. 8. Reservoir Unit. According to the principle of charging a specified flood control fee in flood control areas, a provincial government document was used by the basin management authorities to set flood protection charges. The total flood control capacity of the planned 26 cascade projects in the Lishui River Basin is 2,564 million rn3, of which Jiangya Dam Subproject control capacity would be 740 million i3, accounting for 29 percent of the total. Revenues from the flood protection operations can be identified by the unit charge and total area protected. The flood control fee in Jiangya protection area would be charged as follows: commercial enterprises at 2 percent of their sales; industrial enterprises at 0.2 percent of their total fixed assets; and residences, agriculture, forestry, etc. at 120 kg of rice per ha (valued at Y 0.8/kg of rice). Fees would be paid to the Hunan Provincial Flood Protection Fund which was established in January 1995. Annual payments would be made from this fund to LHPC to cover flood O&M costs.
 - 129 - ANNEX 4 AXn~dix D 9. In addition to the organizational setup, the project would enhance financial management of LHPC by facilitating institution building, including (a) training technical assistance in financial management for LHPC; and (b) agreements with LHPC and the government on financial performance targets that would provide a framework for financial discipline. 10. With a view to obtaining economic efficiency and promoting prudent financial management, assurances would be obtained from LHPC regarding the following financial performance targets for its power and flood control operations: (a) LHPC would take all measures, including, but not limited to, tariff adjustments to ensure that internal cash generation from its power unit is sufficient to maintain a debt-service coverage ratio of no less than 1.4 times in 2000, and no less than 1.4-1.5 times thereafter for its power unit. (b) LHPC/Hunan would set the water rate and flood protection fee to be paid to LHPC at a level that would recover no less than the full O&M costs by the tenth year of operations. LHPC would also take all necessary measures to ensure that the collection rate for the water and flood protection fees would not be lower than 80 percent by the tenth year of operations. 11. To buffer the impact of volatile hydrological conditions, LHPC would also establish a reserve fund of at least 15 percent of annual cash requirements for operations and debt service would be set up and maintained with retained earnings. No new investments would be financed or dividends paid with retained earnings when the ratio is below 15 percent. Objectives of Financial Analysis 12. A financial analysis of LHPC was carried out aimed at estimating an appropriate price level for the power generated and recommending a pricing mechanism that will ensure its realization. The analysis also tested the financial health of LHPC accordingly. Conventional financial analysis is less critical due to the limited operating cost of the hydropower. The model was used to test the various scenarios for power price, LHPC financing, costs, etc. Methodology 13. Taking into account the special features of the project as mentioned above, the analysis was carried out in the following steps. First, separate projected financial statements were established for the corporation as a whole and for the Power Unit. The separable-cost/remaining-benefit approach was used in allocating the common costs to the power unit. Other detailed assumptions are listed in the attachment to this appendix. A roughly estimated tariff level was used for the financial statements at this first stage.
 - 130 - ANNEX 4 Appendix D 14. Second, a constant tariff was derived using the 10-percent required FRR criterion and was compared with the economic tariffs obtained during the economic analysis. This was done to check whether the tariff derived was consistent with real economic data. 15. Third, using the required FRR as a benchmark, the price determination approach was tested for its susceptibility to inflation, smoothness of the derived prices, and whether price levels are appropriate compared to the economic tariff level. The approach is the debt service coverage ratio method (World Bank definition), where tariffs are adjusted every year so that during repayment, predetermined ratios between net revenue and total debt service requirements can be maintained. 16. Fourth, the future financial health of LHPC and the Power Unit was checked under each pricing assumption. 17. A spreadsheet model was prepared to carry out the analysis. The model was designed to test the pricing approach. The model can also handle foreign exchange losses and asset revaluation gains, and test other variables. Fimdings and Conclusions 18. Tariff Level and Pricing Mechanism. The 10 percent required FRR turned out to be acceptable. Based on the debt service coverage ratio-based pricing approach, the above model indicates that the tariff remains approximately constant at 50 fen/kWh (1994 constant price) during the first 10 years after commissioning to achieve the required debt- service coverage. 19. Future Finance Performance. The projections of LHPC's finances for 1998-2005 are summarized in Tables 1 to 4. The projections are based on the assumptions contained in the attachment, which include tariff and flood control charge adjustments needed to allow LHPC to achieve the above financial performance targets and conform to the agreed power tariff, flood control charge action plan. Under these assumptions, LHPC would reach and maintain a strong financial position shortly after the commissioning. By the year when the long-term debt is completely paid, funds that could be used for new investments would be more than Y 2,004 million (at year 2015), assuming no remittances have been paid.

 - 138 - ANNEX 5 FLOOD FORECASTING AND WARNING SYSTEM (In the Middle Reaches of Yangtze River) Introduction 1. The Flood Forecasting and Warning System (FFWS) was originally proposed by the Government for Bank financing under the Yangtze Basin Water Resources Project at a cost of $12.8 million. The PHRD grant has been used to assist its preparation, and preparation of parts of the feasibility study. However, due to policy changes related to internal loan payment issues, the Government decided, at negotiation, that FFWS would be financed entirely by the Central Government, using the local Capital Development Fund. Given the importance of the FFWS in the development of the Yangtze River Basin, the Government intends to implement FFWS along with implementation of the Yangtze Basin Water Resources Project. Background 2. The middle reach of the Yangtze stretches from Yichang to Huko, a length of 938 km (Map IBRD 26385R). The Three Gorges area above Yichang is the main source of flash floods in the middle reach, due to high storm concentrations. The direction of storms often follows the direction of streams. In the middle reaches, the Yangtze River is joined by four local tributaries from the Dongting Lake area: Xiang, Zi, Yuan and Li. A peculiar combination of hydrology and topography make this area subject to frequent and severe flooding, which has long been the main environmental factor affecting the ecosystem and human health in the middle reach of the Yangtze (Tables 1, 2 and 3). 3. Most current engineering measures for flood control in the basin are below the standards required for floods with return periods of more than 50 years (50-year flood). In Hubei, for instance, the existing dikes and levees protect against a 10-20 year flood, and in Hunan production levels are for only 4-7 year floods. Diversion into the retention areas helps protect downstream cities but does not solve the flooding problem due to the large number of people residing in those areas. 4. Despite its economic importance, potential high flood risks, and a well- recorded history of floods, the Yangtze River has an outdated, antiquated and reliable flood forecasting system. Most monitoring equipment and facilities were installed in the 1950s and 1960s. The existing forecasting facilities do not produce accurate measurements of flood water stages, which are crucial to operation of flood diversions into detention areas near the Jingjiang reaches below Yichang. Real time forecasting is generally unavailable, and transmission of information depends largely on wired telephones and telexes sent
 - 139 - A'NNEX 5 through postal services, which are very unreliable during flood seasons when communications are most needed. Even more critical to the operation of a flood- forecasting system and protection of human life in the areas at risk are facilities for issuance of warnings to the large population in the middle reach, which are also out-of- date. Basin Development and National Flood Control and Information Plans 5. The Yangtze Basin Comprehensive Development Plan (approved by the State Planning Commission in 1990) gives top priority to flood control in the middle and lower reach. The focus in the short-to-medium term is on improving river channels in the Jingjiang section, constructing flood diversion and safety areas according to upgraded flood control standards, and improving nonstructural measures for flood control. The Flood Forecasting and Warning System (FFWS) would be a major nonstructural measure. 6. The draft National Flood Control and Information Plan was prepared under the Ministry of Water Resources (MWR) in June 1993. The overall national scheme consists of seven river basin plans prepared by the respective river basin commissions and authorities. The Yangtze Water Resources Commission (YWRC) is responsible for preparation of the flood forecasting and information system plan for the entire Yangtze Basin. The Yangtze plan would be implemented in several phases. The first phase-the proposed FFWS-would deal with the middle reach due to high flood risks in that area. Objectives 7. The main objectives of the middle reach FFWS are to: (a) improve flood forecasting, warning, dispatching and operation in the mid-Yangtze basin to mitigate flood damage and to protect human life, property and economic and social activities in the area; and (b) improve real-time hydrological data and information gathering, analysis and dissemination to better harness the water resources of the basin. FFWS Activities and Components 8. There are six major activities: (a) Installation of 36 telemetry data collection platform (DCP) stations and upgraded monitoring equipment in the upper-middle reach of the Yangtze River; (b) Introduction of large-scale satellite and microwave/VHF radio data transmission technology to improve real-time rainfall and flow discharge data collection; (c) Establishment of a central station in Wuhan and three subcentral stations to receive and process data, and to issue flood warning and operation instructions;
 - 140 - ANNEX 5 (d) Establishment of a real-time database and an interactive flood forecasting system, and incorporation of advanced telecommunication and computerized systems into the current conventional monitoring network; (e) Establishment of a comprehensive microwave and VHF radio communications network to improve flood warning and operations; and (f) Training of YWRC staff and conducting of scientific research. 9. The above activities can be divided into four systems, which would be improved as follows. 10. Hydrological Data Collection System. The system would include installation of 36 DCP stations including: 27 hydrological stations which measure water levels, discharges, sediment and rainfall; and 9 water level stations (pressure transducers and float type recorders). Ten of these DCP will be located at the main stream of the upper reaches between Cuntan an Yichang, and 26 in the middle reaches at the mouths of the four-tributary area of Dongting. Three subcentral stations be set up at Changsha, Yichang and Shashi at existing YWRC hydrological offices. Each station will be responsible for handling field data, sending data to the central station, and carrying out O&M for field stations. 11. Data Transmission System. The system would upgrade data transmission and communication by the use of satellites and line-of-sight VHF radio, and by establishing a microwave line network connected to the existing lines for flood warning and dispatching. The 26 DCPs in the Jingjiang and Dongting Lake regions would be equipped with duplex transmission system (as a system back-up) to allow both satellite and ground radio transmission. Satellite transmission only would be used in the 10 DCPs located upstream between Cuntan and Yichang, where microwave and VHF radio communications are not easily available. 12. Satellite resources available include the Japanese GMS, the Chinese weather satellite Fenyun-2 (FY-2), and the INMARSAT communications satellites. FY-2 is scheduled to be launched in 1995 and will have adequate time slots to accommodate all DCP transmission. FFWS would be easily switched, should the Chinese FY-2 satellite be in orbit by the time this project is in operation in about three years. YWRC is also exploring the possibility of using the INMARSAT-C (for data reporting), whose rental cost has dropped in recent years. 13. Flood Forecasting System. The flood forecasting system would include: (i) establishing a real-time database system for information handling and processing; (ii) introducing better real-time flood forecasting modeling which would be integrated into the systems; and (iii) providing better warning information services. A satellite receiving central station would be set up at YWRC headquarters and would down-link data from the 36 DCPs via satellite, microwave and radio. Computer technology would be used to allow selection of forecasting models, calibration methods and hydrological parameters on-the-fly
 - 141 - ANNEX.5 and in real-time. An "expert system" would be built into calibration algorithms to assist decision making. FFWS would provide almost instantaneous information on rainfall and water stages for decision-making. Advanced computer hardware and software programs would be procured. The system would forecast changes in water levels and flow discharge hydrographs in 14 key control stations from Cuntan down to the middle reach. In addition, scientific research would be carried out on DCP sensor technology (e.g., use of pressure transducers for water level measurements), interface among satellite and ground radio transmissions, flood forecasting models, and software development. 14. Flood Warning and Communications System. The system would consist of installation of a communication network for flood operation and dispatching. This would consist of establishing two backbone microwave lines and a mobile communications network. The new network would connect the three major cities: Yichang, Wuhan and Changsha, and would require 14 additional microwave relay stations to be built under the project. The microwave network would serve three principal functions: (i) transmitting emergency flood warning from the central station to subcentral stations and existing local flood dispatching offices in the middle reaches; (ii) general communication links between Beijing, Wuhan, Yichang, and Changsha for flood operation instructions; and (iii) relay of field data from VHF radio to the central station. 15. The network would cover 6 key flood control districts (Wuhan, Yichang, Jinsha, Shishou, Jianli and Honghu) that are vulnerable to flooding in the middle reach. Mobile communications networks will be set up in the six districts. The new system would improve the timely communication of hydrological information between the Jingjiang dike area and flood diversion areas during emergencies. The network would also provide effective and direct communications between Wuhan, Beijing, and provincial, prefecture and county level offices for flood dispatching along the key flood prone areas in the middle reach. Costs 16. The total investment cost of FFWS is estimated at US$12.8 million, which will be financed entirely by the Central Government. Table 4 presents detailed cost estimates. Estimated annual operation and maintenance costs for FFWS total about US$172,000 (Y 1.5 million), at current prices (1994). Benefits 17. The main benefits of FFWS, when established, are expected to come from real-time hydrological and flood warning information provided to Hunan and Hubei provinces, which are frequently under threat of severe flood. FFWS would improve the accuracy and reliability of flood forecasting and provide incremental lead time of at least three hours in issuing warnings. The expected socioeconomic benefits would include: (i) reduction of human casualties; (ii) better management of the water resources of the basin; and (iii) reduction in the loss of public and private properties. Only the latter benefit has been quantified and included in the economic analysis.
 - 142 - ANNEX 5 18. The ERR is taken as the primary index for economic evaluation of the component, based on a with and without the project comparison. The analysis shows a satisfactory ERR of 28 percent. Sensitivity analysis using switching values shows that the component would remain viable with an 82 percent increase in costs or 46 percent reduction in benefits. 19. The analysis considers the minimum three-hour increase in forecasting time, but does not quantify the value of improved accuracy and reliability of forecasting by FFWS. An increase in forecasting accuracy would reduce economic losses by helping the decision making process on flood diversion (i.e., avoiding diversion and consequent losses when they are unnecessary), and could even help avoid destruction of diversion levees. Therefore, the actual ERR can only be greater than the estimated value above. An additional benefit would be better utilization and management of the water resources of the Yangtze Basin through improved databases, computer facilities and institutional capacity building financed under the component. These benefits, though difficult to quantify, would have a positive long-term impact on the development of the basin. Organization and Implementation 20. YWRC would be the executing agency for FFWS, under the guidance of MWR. A Project Leading Group for FFWS has been set up in YWRC. Its functions will be policy related decision-making, coordination among agencies, review of project technical reports and implementation plans, and reporting to MWR and senior management of YWRC. Under the Leading Group, a Project Management Office (PMO) has been set up to carry out day-to-day management of FFWS implementation. The functions of PMO include coordination and/or management of: project technical design; procurement; financial planning and provision of counterpart funds; implementation and supervision; project audits and progress monitoring; and external affairs. 21. Under the PMO, five units have been established for project implementation: Planning and Finance, Technical Management, Construction Management, General Administration and Procurement (Chart 5). Each unit has two to three staff for running day-to-day management. The actual implementation in each of the above five areas will be carried out by a leading YWRC Bureau which will collaborate with other concerned bureaus of YWRC. 22. The PMO would establish a Project Advisory Group consisting of local and international experts. They would review technical design and assist the PMO in providing technical advice, evaluation, and supervision during project implementation. YWRC would collaborate with the China Meteorological Administration (CMA) for use of weather satellites and for the exchange of hydrological and meteorological data. It will also collaborate with the provincial Water Resources Bureaus in Hubei and Hunan to coordinate with related irrigation, drainage and local flood control activities.
 - 143 - ANNEX S 23. The implementation period for FFWS is expected to be three to five years. The Government plans to implement FFWS simultaneously and in coordination with the Yangtze Basin Water Resources Project. Procurement 24. Procurement for FFWS would consists of two parts, civil works and equipment. It is expected that approximately $7.1 million of imported, high technology equipment will need to be procured. Technical Assistance and Training 25. The FFWS should include technical assistance and training on project management (engineering and financial), interface among various communications subsystems, procurement, and interactive flood forecasting. Technical assistance would be provided by local and international experts and by the project Advisory Group. 26. The FFWS should also include overseas and domestic training for YWRC staff in: (a) technical fields of mobile communications and interactive flood forecasting and computer networks; (b) system operation and maintenance; (c) management fields of project supervision/monitoring and financial management; and (d) management information systems.
