 - 145 - ANNEX 6 SELF-FINANCING IRRIGATION AND DRAINAGE DISTRICTS Introduction and Objectives 1. General. The Yangtze Basin Water Resources Project includes a broad range of water resource activities, a major focus of which is on the development of water resources that are essential to the improvement of China's agricultural performance. The Project intends to establish self-financing irrigation and drainage districts (SIDDs) on a pilot basis, first on two irrigation subprojects in Hubei Province (Zhanghe and Dongfeng), and on one subprojects in Hunan Province (Tieshan). Each SIDD would comprise: (a) a Water Supply Corporation (WSC) that would operate and maintain the reservoirs and main and branch canals; and (b) Water User Associations (WUAs) that would be formed to operate and maintain the lower-level irrigation systems and purchase water from the WSC. After successful SIDDs are developed and tested on a pilot basis, the program would be extended to other subprojects under the project (Yindan and Wenxia in Hubei and Liuduzhai in Hunan), and perhaps other projects in the two provinces and eventually to irrigation projects in other provinces. 2. The objectives of the SIDD pilot projects would include the following: (a) In support of government objectives, to introduce institutional reform that would improve water resource management and promote government policy objectives for cost recovery, self-financing and self-management of irrigation projects. (b) As the basis of the above reforms, to establish SIDDs that would be: (i) legal entities under unified management for each subproject; (ii) based on hydraulic instead of administrative boundaries; (iii) under the ownership, management control and responsibility of farmer-users; (iv) more responsive to user demand and needs; and (v) a basis for future expansion of self-financing and self-management concepts and practices to other irrigation projects in the provinces. (c) To reduce and eventually eliminate dependence on government subsidies of water charges and relieve the government from its historic burden of
 - 146 - ANNEX providing ongoing system operations and maintenance. To help ensure long-run sustainability, irrigation projects must be freed from the limitations and uncertainties of govemment budgets. This is the most fundamental goal of the proposed SIDD establishment, which would be accomplished by: (i) organizing independent entities (WSCs) that would sell water to WUAs based on accurate, equitable standards that would recover capital and operating costs, and in turn provide WUAs with the required management and technical services to assure reliable and adequate water delivery in the long run. This type of operation will require good water measurement capability at all reservoirs, canals and offtakes to enable accurate water accounting in the system; and (ii) forming water user associations (WUA) that would purchase water from WSCs and would increasingly assume ownership and responsibility for the design, construction, maintenance and management of delivery systems at their level. (d) Enact supporting rules, regulations and policies at the Provincial and other relevant levels of govemment to ensure effective management implementation of SIDD procedures and practices, including turning over responsibility and at least a share of ownership and control of facilities to WEA and WSC organizations, and the establishment and enforcement of appropriate water charge rates and standards. 3. SIDD Organizational Characteristics. The ultimate ideal SIDD would have two key organizational characteristics: (a) An independent Water Supply Corporation (WSC), owned and funded by and responsible to water users, other beneficiaries and investors. The WSC would be responsible for constructing, funding and managing the systems that ensure a sustainable supply of water to WUAs at a price that would recover all costs; and (b) Water User Associations (WUAs) that would exert the major influence over decisions related to the design, construction, maintenance and operation of their distribution systems and would pay the full capital, operating and maintenance costs of their distribution systems through water charges and labor contributions. 4. These ideal characteristics provide a target objective and guide for activities under the SIDD development program, and for development of procedures and practices for SIDD establishment. Although this general institutional and organization pattem for self-financing and self-managing irrigation entities has been proven over many centuries in other countries, it will have to be adapted for application under Chinese conditions. A
 - 147 - ANNEX major objective of SIDD pilot programs will be to develop, test and implement the adaptations needed. Inplementation Constraints 5. It is important to take into account the significant constraints in China and in Hubei and Hunan that must be overcome if the implementation of SIDD concepts is to be (even partially) successful. The most critical of those constraints are as follows. 6. Administered Commodity Prices. Of primary importance is the historic fact that farmers do not have access to a free, market-determined pricing system for their produce, especially rice which is the major irrigation crop in the two provinces. Although for some crops, prices are now approaching free-market prices, various controls and impediments to trade still appear to hold rice prices substantially below free-market prices, including possible barriers to export rice across provincial borders. The lowest price for imported rice is currently reported to be about Y 5.00/kg, while the price of the highest- quality domestic rice is Y 3.00/kg. Procurement prices are currently at about Y 0.84- 0.88/kg for low-quality rice (paddy) and Y 1.04-1.08/kg for the highest-quality rice. Although private traders offer a 40 to 50 percent price premium, prices received by farmers are clearly held well below international prices. 7. As a consequence, water charge standards as set at the Provincial level must recognize the farmer's limited ability to pay, and are fixed low-too low to provide sufficient funds for proper system operation and maintenance (O&M). Furthermore, actual collections are only a fraction of the low standards. In the past, the deficit in the amount required for proper system O&M and actual collections, at least in theory, has been made up through government subsidies. In actual practice, however, subsidies were insufficient to provide for effective O&M, and consequently the physical systems deteriorated to the point where major investments are now required for rehabilitation. The system of administered prices and barriers to trade, in combination with subsidies, deprives farmers of the incentives they need to operate, maintain and pay for the O&M of their own systems, reduces their sense of ownership of the systems, and creates a continued dependency on government bureaucracy to provide budgets and take care of the systems. The result is a deteriorating resource base, reduced operating efficiencies and increasing demands on limited government financial resources. 8. Requirement for Continued Subsidy. It will be difficult to establish an equitable standard for water charges sufficient for farmers to pay the full cost of rehabilitation of existing systems, not to mention O&M costs, as long as the price of rice is held down. However, ending the control over the price of a basic commodity such as rice will be a slow and arduous process, and equity requires subsidies to be continued as long as prices remain below free-market rates. The mechanism of price administration/ subsidy also needs careful attention to ensure that it is operated in a manner that does not continue to destroy the farmer incentives to properly operate and maintain their rehabilitated irrigation systems in a sustainable manner after establishment of SIDDs under the project.
 - 148 - ANNEX 9. Lack of Farmer Incentives to Participate. Farmers are not organized into user associations in which they can take collective action for the full O&M responsibility for the system that supplies their water. In order to expect farmers to willingly take such responsibility, they must also be allowed to play a major role in the design, construction/ improvement and operation of the system to ensure, for example, that the design and construction utilizes appropriate technology that the farmers are able to operate and maintain on a sustainable basis. It has been demonstrated many times in other countries that when farmer organizations are involved in the decision-making at each step of the design and construction of their systems, they are not only willing to pay O&M and capital costs, but are also capable of sustained management of O&M, which reduces the necessity of the government to provide subsidies and manpower. 10. Existing System of Water Charge Collection. Another constraint is the existing complex system of fragmented responsibility for water supply management and water charge collection. At present, this comprises: (a) the Provincial Water Resource Bureau (WRB) and their management divisions, which handle O&M at the reservoir and main canal levels; (b) city and county govemment WRBs, including management divisions, district WRBs, water management stations (WMSs), and pump station management divisions, which manage the canal network according to their area of jurisdiction but with little or no effective oversight, control or direction at the system level; and (c) township and village-level water management and water distribution groups. These management units are virtually all overstaffed, and the water charges collected at each level are allocated to the various management units largely to pay staff costs, including salaries and benefits. There are thus strong vested interests at each administrative level. These must be dealt with in order to evolve and upgrade the structure of the management system into an efficient, cost-effective, market-oriented water supply company (the WSC) that would sell water to WUAs and respond effectively to WUA requirements for water and for technical and management assistance. 11. Physical Condition of Pilot Systems. A final major constraint is the poor physical condition of the existing irrigation structures in the pilot project areas, especially in Hubei (in Hunan, the two irrigation subprojects under the project will be newly constructed). At this time, it is questionable whether the designs and cost estimates for system rehabilitation built into the project are sufficient to satisfy farmers that the systems they will be required to take over and pay for under the SIDD concept are in fact within their ability to maintain. It is especially critical in the pilot stage of WUA formation that farmers are convinced that it will be in their best interest to assume full responsibility for their systems. In the past, farmers have generally not been involved in design and layout of their local systems. It is therefore essential that WUAs be formed, trained and brought into this process as soon as possible, and that first priority on their corvee labor requirement for construction be allocated to their own local systems as much as possible. 12. Technical Requirements. System design must be such that it can be operated (at the lower end) by WUAs/farmers, and as indicated above, it must be in satisfactory condition for such operation. Another essential requirement is adequate water measurement capability, which should be done on canals and offtakes to supply measured
 - 149 - EX 6 water deliveries and at all reservoirs supplying the system or located in the area served by the system. This is perhaps more important for operational purposes. However, it is more important for the financial operation of WSCs. To be viable, WSCs must have a complete 'water accounting' similar to their financial accounting system; for them, water is they only commodity the sell, and it is the same as money. Institutional Development Requirements 13. Pilot Project Areas. In order to deal appropriately with the above constraints and develop the institutional, organizational and financial structures required to implement the SIDD concept, selected areas were identified within the existing irrigation subprojects to serve as models, or pilot areas. In Hubei these include the No. 3 Main Canal in Zhanghe, and the Hongtu Branch canal of the No. 1 Main Canal in the Dongfeng Irrigation District. In Hunan the pilot area would be selected from within the Tieshan and Liuduzhai irrigation project areas. 14. Pilot Project Objectives. A prerequisite to the establishment of a sustainable SIDD is the creation of resource-based organizations that would enable farmers to assume greater responsibilities for the operation, maintenance and management of their water supply systems. By attaining this objective, the project intends to benefit from relevant expertise from other countries that have experienced success in similar undertakings. With the use of such human resources, the objectives of the Zhanghe Pilot WUA Project are to: (a) develop a basic set of operational tools and procedures to: (i) organize and establish Water Supply Corporations and Water Users Associations; (ii) introduce the interactive process in which organized farmers or users and local authorities for irrigation development and management would work together using the comparative advantages of each; and (iii) generate and manage the financial, physical and human resources required to develop sustainable irrigation facilities; (b) organize farmers of the pilot area into viable Water User Associations. Tools and procedures will be developed, tested and revised for future use in the establishment of viable WUAs in the project area; (c) train a group of trainers. A team of professionals from Hubei Water Resources Bureau, Zhanghe Management Division, Water Resource Management Station at Zhanghe, and local governments would be trained on WUA organization principles and procedures. These trainers, with continued guidance from established experts as needed, would be used to replicate the pilot project in Dongfeng and in other areas; and
 - 150- ANNEX 6 (d) establish the WSC. This could be done initially by converting the existing management authority to the WSC for operation of the General and Main Canals, and Branch Canals down to the WUA pilot areas. 15. Technical Assistance Requirements. The first phase of Technical Assistance (TA) would employ two experts for a period of about 12 weeks each, beginning in early 1995, in the Zhanghe pilot area. During this initial phase the experts would prepare an inception report, prepare and field test a basic set of WUA organization tools, procedures and training materials, develop and test model agreements between WUAs and WSCs and By-laws for WUAs, and conduct limited on-the-job training of counterpart (WSC) personnel, assisting them to organize one or two WUAs as time allows under the short span of the initial phase of TA. The final report would recommend additional phases of TA required to complete the field testing, revision, training and extension of WUA organizations in the Zhanghe pilot area and later to Dongfeng and other areas, and prepare draft detailed terms of reference for the second stage of the TA. A draft terms of reference for the TA is attached as Appendix A. 16. The TA would also provide for assistance establishment of WSCs. Establishment of effective WSCs early in the program is essential, as they would have the greatest interest in efficient WUAs and will have responsibility for operation and management of the system. This would include development of efficient organizational plans, design of efficient management structures, preparation of model Articles of Association, development and installation of financial accounting and audit systems, development of water measurement and water accounting systems, design and development of an efficient computerized management information system (MIS), and development of a training program for staff and farmers to support SIDD development. WSC TA may if necessary also include assistance for planning the incorporation of existing WRB staff as needed, the role of local government agencies and WRBs in SIDD management, allocation of voting rights in WSC Boards among various stakeholders (e.g., WUAs/Farmers, the WRB, and local governments), allocation of customary (corvee) labor required from farmers to the WSC (and WUAs), and coordination with other concerned agencies, such as the Agriculture Bureau, to organize provision of increased inputs and extension services including credit to WSC areas. Efficient agricultural services are especially important to enable farmers to achieve high returns and be able to pay the increased water charges required. Financial and Cost Considerations for Self-Financing Pilot Subprojects 17. Data Reliability. During preparation and appraisal of the project, there were attempts to clarify the various elements that make up the cost of water in each irrigation subproject so as to enable an analysis of the potential for self-financing. The main difficulty in carrying out those exercises was the lack of reliable data on O&M costs and water revenues. It was difficult to determine the reliability of cost information from second-hand sources, especially since most of it was estimate, and estimates for the same cost categories often varied widely each time they were provided. Conceptual problems were encountered in the government's accounting treatment of estimated costs, especially
 - 151- ANNEX 6 in the definition, classification and accounting for fixed asset depreciation, a large portion of which is comprised of the capitalized labor cost contributions of farmers. It was apparent from the discussions with staff personnel that additional training is needed in the area of cost accounting, especially in view of the objective of establishing WSCs (and other project elements) as independent, semiprivate (or private) entities. 18. Estimated Costs in Hubei Province. Despite questions related to concept and accuracy, however, the data summarized in Table 1 (attached) appear to enable a reasonably comprehensive analysis of the cost of delivering water at each of the four irrigation subprojects in Hunan Province, at least in relative, order of magnitude terms. It should be noted that in two of the Hubei subprojects the actual water charge was not even sufficient to cover wages and benefits (the actual charge in Dongfeng was not available at the time of the analysis). In none of the Hubei subprojects was either the actual or the standard water charge sufficient to cover estimated operating and maintenance costs. 19. Cost Treatment of Flxed Assets. One of the major conceptual problems that needs attention is treatment of fixed assets (depreciation). The present practice in determining the cost of water includes fixed asset depreciation in the calculation. In China the treatment of depreciation is quite different from Western accounting practice. Government regulations reportedly require the maintenance of a bank account that is for the purpose of accruing the periodic cash charge for depreciation. This depreciation fund is then to be used for maintenance, repair and replacement of fixed assets. In Western accounting practice, depreciation is considered a "noncash" write-off of the book value of fixed assets and there is no accumulated reserve of actual cash. Repair and maintenance is generally treated as an expense, while replacement generally adds to the book value of the fixed asset. In any event, for most cases encountered in Hunan and Hubei, water charges were not high enough to enable the accumulation of a cash reserve sufficient to fund even routine maintenance, much less depreciation. While the idea may have merit in theory, it does not seem to be very workable in practice. 20. Cost Treatment of Loan Repayment. Current practice does not now provide for water charges to include loan service (payments of loan principal and interest). In the determination of water charges for the purpose of self-financing, conceptual problems were encountered because of the historic treatment of depreciation (as a cash reserve), which in effect is a proxy for loan repayment. It would be double counting for water users to be required to repay the capital cost of an asset (through loan service) and the cost of depreciating the same asset. If both loan service and depreciation for the full value of fixed assets are included in the water cost calculation, twice the asset value would be recovered (assuming the loan is for the purpose of providing the fixed asset). To further complicate the matter, a significant amount of the fixed asset value not provided by loan funds (generally around 50 percent) is in the value of the labor that is contributed by farmers. Farmers should, of course, not have to pay on the water charge for what they have already contributed in labor. A determination of the cost of water for the purpose of establishing a user rate base water charges needs careful attention to ensure that water charges are fair, accurate and based on sound accounting principles. This type of TA may
 - 152 - ANNEX 6 be required in both Hunan and Hubei to ensure that there is the capability to establish such a rate base. 21. Treatment of Contributed Labor. User fees should not include a provision to repay the cost of an asset that is created and maintained by the labor that is contributed by the users themselves. This is especially true in the event farmer organizations (WUAs) take over ownership and responsibility for the management and maintenance of their own systems. Water charges should then cover only the cost of supplying water from the part of the system that the water users do not own, manage and contribute their own labor for construction and maintenance. If WUAs/farmers do contribute labor to higher levels of the system-to the WSC-their water charge or purchase price for water can be adjusted accordingly. Water users should be able to reduce their water charges by taking responsibility for larger portions of the system (e.g., upper levels of the branch canals), and by selling water to other users who have no ownership of or O&M responsibility for the system. 22. Incentives for Farmers to Participate. Benefits related to water charges and labor allocation to their own systems as above are quickly recognized by farmers and will provide strong incentives to participate. In addition, the application of the concept of farmer organization (WUAs) is workable in the long run only if farmers are also allowed to assume the decision-making and management roles, along with the liability for O&M and debt repayment. This gives them a real element of control over the system on which they depend and for which they will take increasing responsibility. Perhaps the most critical factor, however, is a reliable and sustainable supply of water, without which farmers and the WUA cannot survive. Water stress and disputes will reduce willingness for cooperation among users. This is especially important given the almost complete lack of a system of clearly defined and enforceable water rights. 23. Estimated Costs in Hunan Province. In Hunan Province the cost of water in Liuduzhai and Tieshan vary widely. Water cost estimates for these two projects are shown in Table 2 below. There are two main reasons for such a variance. First, whereas the investment in each project is relatively the same, Liuduzhai will supply less than 40 percent of the water supplied by Tieshan, resulting in a much higher unit cost per cubic meter of water for Liuduzhai. Second, Tieshan has a sizable municipal water supply component, which can subsidize the irrigation component and keep water charges to farmers very low (at about Y 1.00/100 e3). The proposed weighted average water charge for Tieshan is about Y 17.46/100 n3, which would be sufficient to fund the total cost of the project, including full loan service (estimated at Y 16.14/100 in3). Liuduzhai, on the other hand, is a very poor area. A subsidy undoubtedly will be required to cover the high cost of water, even without consideration of debt coverage. Farmers' Ability to Pay 24. For self-financing of irrigation districts to work, farmers must be willing and able to pay the cost of water service. The tables discussed above indicate substantial increase in water charges will be needed even to cover the full cost of O&M, compared
 - 153 - ANNEX 6 to present water charges. Policy in both Hubei and Hunan is to recover the full capital cost (excluding the farmer's direct labor contribution). However, it is essential to preserve the farmers' incentive to use the irrigation, and the new "self-financing" water charges should not take too big a share of incremental farm income. Both provinces recognize this and have suggested an informal limit of 10 percent of net income as the maximum water charge. Based on the cost data discussed above and the farm model data used in the financial analysis for the project, it appears that coverage of O&M costs plus repayment (amortization) of part or all of the Bank subloan under the project are approximately within those limits. However, recovery of all costs (i.e., including the local counterpart fund contribution and "depreciation") may not be feasible in all cases and is likely to be difficult (Table 3). Budget Support for WSCs and Cost Recovery Studies 25. Currently, water charges are generally insufficient to cover the full costs of irrigation service, and provincial and local governments generally provide a subsidy (budget support) to make up the difference between costs of service and revenue from water charges. However, because government budgets are tight and subsidies for irrigation are expected to decline in the future, the need to establish SIDD concepts is important to ensure the long-run sustainability of the irrigation and drainage schemes and the viability of investments under the project. As SIDDs are expected to be self-financing, such subsidies would not be needed in the long run. In the near term, however, continuation of budget support at current (1993) real levels for WSCs during the project period would be needed to maintain farmer incentives to participate, and to avoid discrimination against farmers who participate in project SIDDs compared to farmers in nonproject areas. This temporary budget support would allow gradual phase-in of water charges at 'self- financing" levels, which would be substantially higher than at present. To eliminate the need for long-term budget support, SIDDs (WSCs and WUAs) would have to both raise water charges and cut costs. This should be covered in the SIDD Cost Recovery studies under the project, which could be included under the proposed SIDD TA. Conclusion 26. It is apparent from this analysis that the application of the concept of self- financing should be considered on a case-by-case basis, taking into consideration the individual physical, technical and financial aspects of each subproject as well as the ability of water users to pay. The potential for success in the implementation of the self-financing concept is a direct function of the government's commitment to carry out the required institutional reforms centered around the organization of WUAs and WSCs, the turnover of physical facilities in physical condition that enables sustained maintenance by users, accurate determination of water costs, the eventual elimination of administered commodity prices, and the establishment of water charges that will cover at least full O&M and loan service (minus the subsidy that may be retained in certain cases).

Field visits were made in the Hubei pilot areas and discussions were held with farmers and concerned authorities to obtain a general physical and organizational overview of the areas. Some of the findings and observations are summarized below. (a) The physical boundaries of the pilot areas defined earlier were based on administrative boundaries. Unless the pilot areas consist of well-defined hydrological units, the ability to replicate procedures developed and tested in the pilot area would be limited. (b) Many of the physical structures within the pilot areas are in poor condition, and financial provisions for rehabilitation are wholly inadequate. Attempts to organize Water User Associations in areas where the physical structures have substanfally deteriorated would have little or no success without a concurrent program for their effective rehabilitation. Otherwise, there is no incentive for farmers to organize or to assume added financial, operating or maintenance burdens, nor should they be expected to agree to do so. The Environment and Resettlement Panel of experts has been established. Part I: EMMP for Jiangya Reservoir Development Management Arrangements 2. Jiangya Reservoir would be owned and operated by the Lishui Hydro and Power Corporation (LHPC), which is jointly owned by the Ministry of Water Resources and the Hunan Provincial Government. Construction of the project would be the responsibility of the Hunan Water Resources Project Management Office of the Provincial Water Resources Bureau, which will ultimately be absorbed into LHPC. 3. LHPC includes an Environmental and Resettlement Division (ERD), which will have a director and four staff. The four staff members will comprise: a scientist (botanist), two water resources engineers and an economist/management specialist. The ERD will have the responsibility for implementation of the EMMP, which is summarized in the following sections, and for supervision of the resettlement program. 4. During construction, it is proposed that ERD staff would act as inspectors and advisors to the Supervising Construction Engineer (the Engineer) on environmental matters. Their responsibilities would include: I/ Research Institute of Water Resources Protection for the Yangtze (1994), Environmental hImpad Assessment for Wotr Resources Projeci in Hunan and Hubel Provincs, April, p. 192.

During operation, it is envisaged that the ERD would concern itself primarily with environmental management and protection of the reservoir and the surrounding catchment. The scope of its work in this regard would be defined by the results of various data collection and analytical activities that have been provided for under the EMMP. EMMP Sumlmary and Overall Cost Estimate 6. EMMP Stummary. The EMMP encompasses management and control of project development activities (i.e., reservoir construction and resettlement) and preparation for long-term environmental monitoring and management during the operational phase. The plan is divided into five parts: * PART A: establishment of the ERD, which specifies the equipment and facilities that will be procured to support the operations of the Division and also provides a general outline of the Divisions's responsibilities (see Table 3); * PART B: enviromnental management of the reservoir construction program, which specifies the management and inspection activities that will be carried out to maintain environmental management standards during the construction phase. Most inspection activities will be carried out by staff of the ERD but some tasks will be contracted out to local institutions that will work under the direction and report to the ERD (see Table 4);

Summary of Estimated EMMP Costs. The costs associated with environmental monitoring and management have been divided into three categories: (a) costs that will be directly incurred by ERD, other than staff salaries and routine operating costs, and will require a budget allocation. The expenditures are almost exclusively for the procurement of contracted services such as health inspections, water quality monitoring, etc., the size of the service packages is generally small (<Y 200,000) and most of the services are highly specialized and in most cases, there are no alternative suppliers. These services would be procured through Force Account. The cost estimates also include several provisional suns to cover investments and activities that would be determined on the basis of a mid-term progress review and may or may not be expended; (b) costs that will be incurred by LHPC, and are covered in the other budget estimates; and (c) costs that could be incurred by the construction contractors and will be covered in their tender prices. These costs are only very rough estimates and are included solely for the purposes of estimating the total financial resources that could be applied to environmental management. 8. Part II: Environmental Management Plan for Four Lakes Development Management Arrangements 9. The EMMP for the proposed Four Lakes development consists of a schistosomiasis control program, an extension program on agrochemical handling and management; and, a water quality investigation program to monitor and analyze water pollution sources in the Four Lakes area and make recommendations to the County and Provincial governments on strategies to control the deteriorating water quality situation in the area. 10. Due to the limited scope of the EMMP, it is not proposed to establish a special environmental unit to manage the program. Instead, it is proposed that the program will be managed and organized by the Research Institute for Water Resources Protection for the Yangtze (RIWRPY). Scope and Costs of the Program 11. Disease Control Program. The scope of work will include: education of contractors and workers on schistosomiasis control procedures; medical checks of construction workers and issuing of health cards; periodic follow-up worker health checks; survey of oncomelia breeding areas and assistance in spoil disposal planning (to bury breeding areas where possible); and the provision of other health care advice as required. 12. This work would be carried out by the County hospitals, the County Epidemic Prevention Stations and the Jingzhou Research Institute of Anti-Schistosomiasis, organized and coordinated by RJWRPY. The estimated total cost of the program is Y 500,000 over five years. 13. Agrochemical Extension Program. The project will result in intensified agricultural development in the area, which will be accompanied by increased usage of agrochemicals including pesticides/herbicides and fertilizers. The extension program will be designed to inform farmers on the safe handling, storage and application of these chemicals by way of booklets, posters, radio broadcasts and presentations. The work will be carried out by the County Bureaus of Agriculture and the estimated cost is Y 200,000. 14. Water Quality Monitoring and Pollution Study. Although the EIA concluded that the Four Lakes development in itself would not have a significant adverse environmental impact, it represents further intensification of land use in an area that is already subject to significant water quality pressures due to agriculture, industrial and urban developments. The proposed study is intended to identify the main sources of pollution, estimate existing pollution loadings and destinations, assess the state of the aquatic environment in the Four Lakes area, make projections of potential future pollution
 - 170 - ANNEX 7 loadings and water quality and prepare a water quality control strategy for consideration by both County and Provincial governments. The study would be based on existing data, supplemented by additional water quality and pollutant discharge monitoring as required. 15. It is proposed that the work would be carried out jointly by RPWRPY, local County Environmental Monitoring Stations and the Hubei Province Environmental Monitoring Center, with overaU project management being the responsibility of RIWRPY. The estimated cost of the study is Y500,C000 and a period of five years has been allowed for its completion, to allow adequate time for supplementary monitoring. B. RESJrnEMENT-JIANGYA RESERVOIR AND DAM Introduction 16. The Jiangya Dam subproject will affect a total of 15,783 people. Of these, 3,196 people will be partiaUy affected. They will lose their agricultural land but not their house, and wiU require economic rehabilitation. The majority, or about 12,587 people, will be physicaUy displaced-567 people for the dam and 12,020 people for the reservoir. It is estimated that the population of those to be physicaUy relocated wiUl increase, primarily due to population growth, to about 13,761 people by the time resettlement is completed in 1997. 17. This subproject wil affect nine townships in three counties, that is, Cili and Shanzhi counties in Hunan Province and Hefeng county in Hubei Province. The affected area is largely agricultural, with about 90 percent of the population registered as agricultural. The average size of agricultural households is 3.8 persons, with a labor force ratio of about 50 percent. Education levels in the area are relatively low, with less than 1 percent of the population having obtained senior middle school or higher level of education; about 42 percent of the population has primary school level education. The plan divides the resettlement program into phases as per the project's construction program. The initial phase involves resettlement of 567 people at the dam site and has been completed. The strategy involves: (a) resettlement of about 11,230 agricultural resettlers on land at higher elevations, above the final reservoir level of 236 m; (b) resettlement of 2,640 agricultural people in the suburbs of Cili town due to lack of arable land near the original location; (c) resettlement of 1,125 people, from the six affected market towns to the new sites for the towns; and (d) allowing people, if they prefer, to move to other areas to live with relatives. 22. The following actions would be taken to implement the above strategy: (a) Development of Resettlement Sites, Housing and Infrastructure Reconstruction. This program involves development and construction of 29 village sites and six market towns. The original floor space of the affected housing, that is, 425,000 m2, will be rebuilt by the resettlers from their compensation monies. The local government and resettlement offices will be responsible for completing land development activities and providing infrastructure at the resettlement sites prior to the moving date. Infrastructure in market towns will include provision of water supply, drainage, electricity and, if necessary, sanitation. (b) Reestablishment of Livelihood. A majority of the resettlers (75 percent) will be provided with farmland at higher elevation, primarily for cultivation of fruits, tea and Chinese medicinal herbs. About 19 percent of the resettlers will be supported by 1,000 new jobs that will be created through investment of resettlement funds in village and township enterprises. Of the remaining 6 percent, 3 percent of the resettlers will be involved in aquaculture, and another 3 percent will continue with grain farming. The task of reestablishment of resettlers' livelihoods will involve development of about 34,000 mu of land and 16 enterprises. Resettlement Cost Estimates 23. Recent Resettlement Experience 26. Project authorities have gained some resettlement experience under the Tieshan irrigation subproject (853 people) and the Liuduzhai irrigation subproject (651 people). These resettlement programs have been successful in providing good-quality replacement housing and agricultural land to maintain incomes of resettlers. In addition, 567 people have already been resettled at the dam site. The resettlers have constructed superior-quality housing, often better than their original house. Investment in and development of enterprises has, however, lagged behind.  - 203 - ANNEX 10 ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL ANALYSIS Prices 1. At present, the prices of agricultural products in the project area, except for cotton and tobacco, are free-market prices or coexist with free-market prices. State procurement prices consist of a ceiling and a floor-guaranted price. In general, they are close to free-market prices after several adjustments, except for rice. All direct government subsidies have been eliminated. 2. In Hubei and Hunan, output prices have risen steadily for the past several years. The crops' purchasing price index in 1993 rose 14.5 percent from 1992, includ- ing a grain price rise of 16.8 percent, cash crops of 13.6 percent, livestock products of 17.4 percent, and other crops of 5.1 percent. The official guaranteed price in 1994 increased 25 percent from 1993 for grain (Y 0.8/kg to Y 1.0/kg), 21.1 percent for cotton (Y 6.6/kg to Y 8/kg), and 57 percent for rapeseed (Y 1.4/kg to Y 2.2/kg). The unit price for vegetables, fruits, meat, and aquatic products have increased also. These increases have brought official prices of wheat, maize, and oilseeds closer to local, open-market prices. 3. Cotton and tobacco are the only commodities under the project that are still subject to state contract purchase at prices announced annually by the provincial government. Farmers required to produce them according to production quotas or contracts. 4. Farmers will be able to sell their incremental project output at local market prices (except cotton and tobacco). It is expected that most of the incremental crop and livestock production of the project would be consumed in the project areas or in other domestic markets. Project farmers will also be able to buy sufficient quantities of fertilizer, agrochemicals and other farm inputs at free-market prices, although in general prices for those items have risen faster than for grain prices. Input prices rose from 1993 to 1994 by 29 percent for urea, 14 percent for phosphate fertilizer, and 30 percent for agricultural chemicals. 5. Prices Used in Analysis. Input and output prices used in crop budgets for financial analysis of the project components are either 1994 average free-market prices or official prices, based on data from project authorities (Table 1). For the economic analysis, World Bank commodity price projections have been used to calcu- late the farm-gate value of rice, wheat, maize, soybean, cotton, timber, urea, DAP, and potassium chloride, with appropriate adjustments for nutrient content, domestic, and intemational transport and handling costs. The values for most other farm inputs and
 - 204 - ANNEX 10 outputs have been considered equivalent to the financial price or adjusted by the stan- dard conversion factor (see para. 14). Financial Analysis 6. Substantial employment, income enhancement and poverty alleviation will accrue from increased production of crops, forestry, livestock, and aquaculture prod- ucts. The production will be from irrigation and drainage subprojects, and nonwater subprojects. Further benefits will accrue from flood control and power generation of Jiangya Dam, and from increased flood protection and warning time on the middle Yangtze River. 7. Financial analyses have been carried out for the principal components based on detailed crop budgets prepared for the annual and perennial crops, reflecting representative scenarios in all components and subprojects. Selected crop budget models are attached in Table 2. In analyzing output by crop, investment and produc- tion costs are valued at the average annual market price or official price in 1994, and use conservative assumptions on yields and commodity prices. Given the price and cost structures in each subproject area, as well as the objective of the project, rates of return (ERRs) for all components are acceptable. The FRRs on individual components ranged from 12.4 (Table 3), protection forestry to 37.7 percent (aquaculture, turtle hatcheries). Irrigation and drainage components ranged from 14.7 (Liuduzhai in Hunan) to 23.5 percent (Yindan in Hubei). The forestry subproject ERR is 22.8 percent; within each component, it ranged from 12.4 to 25.3 percent with different kind of trees: the timber is 19.1 percent, fruit is 25.3 percent, and the lowest rate, 12.4 percent, occurs for plantings of protection forestry that does not always pay in the short run, although trees are a critical element in the comprehensive conservation of soil and water. The grass- land and livestock components are 16 percent for uplands and about 18 percent for lowlands. The aquaculture subproject is 30.2 percent, including 37 percent for finger- ling ponds, 17.1 percent for intensive fishponds, 37 percent for the new turtle hatchery and larva turtle ponds, 22 percent for adult turtle ponds, 19.3 percent for new finger- ling ponds, and 27.9 percent for the extensive lake component. Agricultural Benefits 8. Incremental Production. The major benefits of the project derive from incremental agricultural production and rural incomes. The irrigation and drainage components will provide incremental field crop production of 2.6 million tons of grain, and 0.21 million tons of cash crops. This increment is valued, net of on-farm labor costs, at $203 million annually. Incremental fruit production of 40,881 tons is valued at $7.93 million, while 0.29 million m3 of incremental timber production is valued at $8.87 million, 42,053 additional head of cattle at $4.51 million, and 21,031 additional tons of aquatic products at $6.2 million. In total, these components would generate an incremental value of $231 million annually.
 - 205 - ANNEX 10 9. Income and Poverty Alleviation. The farm model analysis shows a substantial increase in farmer income with improvements in irrigation and drainage, land utilization, crop pattern, and production. Several items have been taken into account to assess the impact on typical household income, such as: various incremental taxes (agricultural tax, special product tax and fee, etc.); the project loan repayment, which includes farmer labor contribution requirement allocated to each household (total- ing about 15 percent of the project cost); up to 10 percent of the annual net family income used to repay the bank loan starting six years after full development; and an incremental water charge that covers the full operation and maintenance fee for the new and rehabilitated irrigation and drainage system. The standard charge for these items in each subproject area is presented in the typical household farm model (Table 5). 10. Many farm households were investigated in the project area to represent typical beneficiary families. The typical farm households are selected in every subproj- ect area based on the three current income levels (high, middle, and low). The main category in typical household farm models includes detailed income, and expenditures for different income levels. The average growth rate of household income at year 8 will be 55.6 percent, with an annual average growth rate of 5.7 percent (Table 4). 11. The net income of farm families who adopt improved or new technolo- gies under the project would increase substantially. Farm models have indicated that in Hubei the project would increase farm household average income in irrigated and drain- aged areas about 50 percent, from Y 1,153 to Y 1,414 in Dongfeng; Y 1,411 to Y 1,636 in Zhanghe; and Y 1,248 to Y 1,583 in Wenxia. However, the project would double or triple the incomes of adoptees in many villages where comprehensive mea- sures were implemented (in the Sihu and Yindan areas). 12. In addition, the project would directly help to alleviate poverty in the Hunan project area, especially for Luduzhai subproject area, which is classified by the government as among the poorest areas in China. Ten percent of households are cur- rently at the low-income level (below Y 300), 65 percent at the middle-income level (Y 300-500), and 12 to 13 percent of households at the high-income level (above Y 500). The per capita income in Tieshan is about Y 436. The project would increase farm income for the typical household in Hunan about 57 percent, from Y 462 to Y 772 in Tieshan irrigation area, and Y 439 to Y 646 in Liuduzhai area. 13. Employment. Employment opportunities generated by the project would help reduce seasonal underemployment among the rural labor force in and around proj- ect areas. At full development, average incremental labor requirements for farming activities in crops, forestry, aquatic products, grasslands and livestock production would average 94.52 million person-days, 1.37 million person-days, 0.81 million person-days, and 1.11 million person-days per year, respectively, equivalent to a total of 0.33 mil- lion new jobs. In each subproject area, land construction and preparation would require additional hired labor, which is amply available from the underemployed labor pool, throughout the year in each province.
 - 206 - ANNEX 10 Economic and Sensitivity Analysis 14. Assumptions. Economic analysis has been carried out for the all sub- projects (irrigation and drainage, soil improvement, forestry, grassland, aquaculture development, Jiangya Dam and FFWS), and for the project as a whole. World Bank price projections or export pnces actually realized in China were taken to estimate farm-gate prices in 1994 constant terms for traded inputs and outputs (Table 6). The standard conversion factor of 0.97 is applied to all nontraded items (conversion factors for investment cost items are listed in Table 7). All economic values were converted to local currency at the prevailing official exchange rate of Y 8.7 to $1.0, a discount rate of 12 percent was used, which is considered to approximate the opportunity cost of capital in China. All project costs, including project investment and production costs, working capital, and physical contingencies have been taken into account in estimating the economic costs of the project, but price contingencies, interest, and taxes were omitted. 15. Agriculture. Based on the above assumptions and comparing costs and benefits over a period of 20 years, the economic rates of return (ERRs) for selected agricultural components range between 17.6 percent (for Liuduzhai imgation) to 34.5 percent (for aquaculture), depending on the assumed cropping pattern, the size of the irrigated and drainage area, and the investment costs. The overall project ERRs for Hubei and Hunan subproject area are 25.7 and 18.3 percent with a net present value of about Y 1,257 and Y 972 million, Table 8. 16. Sensitivity analysis on the ERRs for each of the project irrigated areas and nonwater components has been carried out with switching values to identify before the project becomes economically nonviable and how far costs can rise or benefits can fall. Table 8 shows that the overall project is not rendered unprofitable by significant changes in cost or benefits: benefits will need to be 30 percent lower than estimated or incremental costs 40 percent higher before the ERR will fall to 12 percent. The sensi- tivity analysis indicates, even though the proportion of protection forestry investment is larger and benefits are less than in other components, forestry as a subproject is satis- factory as well. The detailed analysis can be found in the project files. 17. Jiangya Multipurpose Dam. The control of floods and supply of power and energy to the Hunan power grid are the primary benefits of the Jiangya component. Among other Jiangya benefits are improved water supply for domestic use and irriga- tion (although its distribution system is not covered by the project and would be con- structed later); and improved river transportation for navigation and tourism. These benefits are small in relation to the total project benefits and not quantified here. 18. Flood Control. The flood-control storage capacity of Jiangya Dam is about 0.74 billion m3, enough to raise the flood security standard of the Western Dongting Lake Area from the present flood return period of 1 in 4 years to 1 in 17 years, and for the section between the dam site and Sanjiangkou up to a 20-year return
 - 207 - ANNEX 10 period flood.l/ Thus, the dangers of normally occurring floods can be avoided, and the average peak water level and losses caused by large floods can be reduced. Analy- sis of historic floods over 40 years and the 11 floods since 1935 that caused major damage indicates that, with Jiangya Dam, flooding of polder areas could have been avoided for 9 of the 11 floods, flood diversions would not have been required, and 2,950 ha of inundated farmland would be saved each year, except for years of abnormal flooding from the Yangtze River (in 1935 and 1954). For floods with peak discharges of the 20-year flood level, flooding of polder areas could be eliminated or reduced by about 85 percent (depending on flood volume), and about 9,330 ha of inundated farm- land resulting from flood diversion can be saved. For the 50-year flood, the safety of key areas can be guaranteed by combining Jiangya Dam project with flood detention and flood storage areas. Flood diversion can be decreased by 642 million m3 and 12,460 ha of inundated farmland can be protected. 19. Methodology and Assumptions. Flood control benefits are calculated as the reduction in expected average annual flood damage due to operation of Jiangya dam. Underlying estimates of expected average annual damages with and without the project were made separately for the polder area (below Shimen County) and the river valley area (above Shimen County), and obtained by estimating damage that major historical floods would cause under the present conditions. Recorded losses of 11 major floods since 1935 were adjusted to derive their equivalent damages under current conditions. 20. For the pokder area, extra volumes of flood water under various flood frequencies were first calculated. The corresponding polder area required to absorb the flood, i.e., the polder area to be inundated, was then derived based on an assumed water depth of 2 to 5 m. Average unit flood damage based on the survey of four typical polder areas (Table 9) was multiplied by area to derive the total average annual flood damages. In addition, the reduction of flood control cost with the project is taken into account for the benefit analysis, indicating a flood control and emergency handling cost of Y 6.8 million can be saved annually. For the nlver valley area, due to the sharp increase of water level during flooding, the value of dikes is limited. Therefore, the stage-damage relationship was established to estimate the damage under various flood frequencies. 21. Flood damages include lost agricultural and industrial production, personal and public property, etc. This was investigated by a team from Hunan and Yangtze Water Resources Commission in the flood zone of Hunan and Hubei at the beginning of 1992. They applied a sampling and synthesizing method. The unit of flood damage per ha was calculated comprehensively based on this investigational data, assuming damage increases at the rate of 4 percent per year to reflect the impact of economic growth. An inflation rate of 30 percent was used to adjust the recorded losses in 1992 to 1994 prices. 1/ A 20-year flood is the largest level of flood with a 0.05 probaility of occuring in any single year.
 - 208 - ANNE 10 22. Flood Control Benefit. Based on the assumptions described above, the expected annual flood control benefits under the current conditions calculated in 1994 constant prices were Y 122.51 million. The benefits were assumed to increase by 4 percent annually for the first 10 years of the project, and 3 percent annually thereafter, to reflect future economic development. Using the method of separable costs/remaining benefits to allocate common costs of the dam, the ERR for the flood control component is 22 percent, and the total flood control benefits, discounted at 12 perct to the beginning of 1995, are Y 436 million (Table 10). 23. Power Generation. The average installed capacity and average power generation per capita in Hunan province is only 60 percent of the corresponding value for all China. During the 1980s, the growth rate of power generation capacity and energy generation developed relatively slowly, 4.1 percent and 4.5 percent, respectively, in 1985. However, the annual economic growth rate is at 10.47 percent, resulting in a serious shortage of electricity in the province. Due to power shortages, 20 percent of industrial capability cannot be used; the chemical and metallurgical enterprises cease production 2 to 4 months annually, and farmland cannot be irrigated or drained. The total shortage of power was 1,772 million kWh in 1989, with loss of production at about Y 5,446 million; and 1,500 million kWh in 1990, with loss of production of about Y 4,506 million, and 1,000 MW in 1992. 24. Load forecasting, based on the differing assumptions about economic growth and power demand for Hunan Power Grid, has been derived by the Beijing Economic Research Institute (BERI). The Jiangya Dam has a normal reservoir storage water level of 236 e3, corresponding to total regulating reservoir volume 1,165 million ml3, of which 740 million i3 are for flood control and other for power generation. The installed capacity of Jiangya hydropower plant is 300 MW. The plant would generate 756 GWh per year on average. Additional power generation of 58 million kWh represents the increased energy output of the downstream stages due to Jiangya Dam, half of which is taken into account by the project economic analysis (29 million GWh). After the dam is in operation, it will bear a peak load of 390 GWh and a middle load of 395 GWh in the Hunan power grid. 25. Methodology and Assumptions. Power benefits from Jiangya are calculated by the Electric System Planning Model of BERI (a multiregional, integrated generating system expansion optimization model), which developed the least-cost expansion plans for the Hunan Power Grid with and without Jiangya. The present value of all capital and operating costs, except the Jiangya cost, is then calculated for each expansion scenario. The replacement for Jiangya in the alternative expansion plan is thermal capacity. Thermal candidates included in the planning studies were 300 MW and 600 MW coal-fired plants; 100 MW distillate-fired, combined-cycle plants; and 10 MW distillate-fired gas turbines. Characteristics of the thermal expansion altematives used in the analysis are presented in the following table:

Based on these assumptions, the power tariff in the proposed project is Y 0.44/kWh. Since local manufacturers are capable of meeting only 70 percent of the demand for new generating capacity, consumers are willing to pay at least this alternative cost. Power from all new thermal power plants in China is priced to achieve loan repayment (assuming fully debt-financed) over a 10-year period. Resulting prices to the grid are substantially above long-run marginal cost. All incremental consumption beyond 1983 levels is charged at this "new" price so there is ample evidence to demonstrate that consumers' willingness to pay is well above long-run marginal cost, based on thermal generation. The alternative cost used here, therefore, provides a lower-bound estimate of the power supply benefits from the Jiangya hydropower component. 27. Cost Allocation. Common costs of the Jiangya component (dam, flood handling, resettlement, boatlift facilities, and environmental treatment) are allocated to power and flood control using the "separable costs/remaining benefits" methodology. This results in 49.1 percent of common costs allocated to power and 50.9 percent allocated to flood control. 28. All assumptions and conversion factors used in calculation were consistent throughout the economic analysis of the all components. Import parity price was used for capital costs of thermal generation. Coal for future, large power plants in Hunan is likely to come from Shanxi. The shadow price used for coal was based on the export price at Qinhuangdao seaport ($35 per ton at 6,000 kcallkg). Transportation costs between Shanxi mine-mouth and Qinhuangdao were deducted, yielding a mine- mouth, export-parity price. Rail transport costs between the mine-mouth and Hunan were then added to obtain the shadow price in Hunan.

The economic benefits of Jlangya is composed of two parts: capacity benefit from investment and fixed O&M cost of alternative candidates, and energy generation benefit from the alternative cost replacing energy generation of Jiangya. Economic value of this power is Y 0.44/kWh. Using the method of separable costs/remaining benefits to allocate common costs, ERR for the power component is about 16 percent and total net present value of power generation, discounted at 12 percent to the begnning of 1995, is Y 319 million (Table 11). 30. ERR and Sensitivity Ansalysis. The proposed Jlangya subproject would yield an estimated ERR of about 19 percent for the base-case scenario. Its NPV, at a 12-percent discount rate, is Y 764 million C(able 12). Assuming the opportumity cost of capital is 12 percent, switching value calculations indicate that the Jiangya multipurpose dam benefits would have to be reduced by 40 percent to reduce the ERR of the whole subproject to 12 percent. Similarly, to reduce the EIRR to 12 percent, the total cost for the whole subproject would have to increase 34 percent. Switching value calculations indicate that none of the liklly cases would reduce the ERR of the whole subproject to 12 percent (rable 13).

doc.repnme: China - Yangtze Basin Water Resources Project
doc.abstracts: The Yangtze Basin Water Resources Project will raise agricultural production and incomes; reduce the risk and impact of floods; introduce a more sustainable and cost-effective system of operation and maintenance of irrigation and drainage schemes; and promote institutional reform and strengthening and improve planning and environmental monitoring in the water sector. Key institutional development objectives will be to introduce comprehensive river basin management, and self-financing irrigation and drainage districts based on farmer participation. This will promote cost recovery, decentralization of services delivery, and participation by users which are key elements of Government and Bank water resources policy. The project will be the first Bank Group supported comprehensive water resources operation in China.
